reference_steps: Raw materials were weighed according to stoichiometric ratio and ball-milled with zirconia balls in nylon jars for 12 hours.
Additional 2 wt% PbO was introduced for compensating volatilization during sintering process.
After drying at 120°C, powders were calcined at 900°C for 4 hours and re-milled for another 6 hours.
Dried powders were mixed with polyvinyl alcohol binder and sieved through screen mesh.
Particles were pressed into pellets with diameter of 12 mm and thickness around 1.2 mm under uniaxial pressure of 15 MPa.
Green pellets were fired at 500°C for 2 hours for binder burn-out.
Specimens were sintered at 1190-1250°C for 1 hour.
Cooling process was controlled at 3°C/min till 600°C to prevent ceramics from cracking.
Natural cooling without quenching was performed below 600°C.
Sintered pellets were coated with silver paste on both surfaces and dried at 120°C for 30 minutes.
Samples were polarized in silicon oil at 150°C with DC electric field up to 4 kV/mm for 30 minutes.
test_steps: Raw materials of PbO, K2CO3, Nb2O5, and Ta2O5 were weighed according to the stoichiometric ratio and ball-milled with zirconia balls in nylon jars for 12 h.
Additional 2 wt% of PbO was introduced for compensating the volatilization of PbO during the sintering process.
After drying at 120 °C, the powders were calcined at 900 °C for 4 h and re-milled for another 6 h.
The dried powders were mixed with polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binder and sieved through a screen mesh.
The particles were pressed into pellets with a diameter of 12 mm and thickness around 1.2 mm under uniaxial pressure of 15 MPa.
The green pellets were fired at 500 °C for 2 h for binder burn-out.
All specimens were sintered at 1190–1250 °C for 1 h.
The cooling process was controlled at 3 °C/min till 600 °C to prevent the ceramics from cracking. A natural cooling without quenching is performed below 600 °C.
The optimal sintering temperature was determined to be 1230 °C via analyzing the bulk densities obtained from the Archimedes principle.
For piezoelectric property measurements, the sintered pellets were coated with silver paste on both surfaces and dried at 120 °C for 30 min to solidify the electrodes.
All samples were polarized in silicon oil at 150 °C with a DC electric field up to 4 kV/mm for 30 min.

reference_steps: Raw chemicals were weighed according to stoichiometric ratio and ball-milled for 12 hours with ethyl alcohol as medium.
Mixture was dried and calcined at 1250°C for 2 hours with heating rate of 5°C/min.
Calcined powder was ball-milled again in ethanol for 12 hours and dried at 90°C for 3 hours.
Mixture was pressed into pellets with diameter of 8 mm using 5 wt% PVA as binder.
Pellets were heated at 500°C for 5 hours to volatilize the PVA.
Pellets were sintered at 1450°C for 4 hours in air.
All samples were aged at room temperature for one week before testing.
Samples were coated with Ag electrodes on both sides and heated at 700°C for 30 minutes.
Samples were poled in silicone oil bath at 100°C and cooled to 0°C under DC field of 3 kV/mm.
test_steps: The raw chemicals of BaCO3, TiO2, HfO2, Fe2O3 were weighed according to the stoichiometric ratio, and ball-milled for 12 h with ethyl alcohol as the medium.
The mixture was dried and then calcined at 1250 ℃ for 2 h with a heating rate of 5 ℃/min.
The calcined powder was ball-milled again in ethanol for 12 h, and dried at 90 ℃ for 3 h.
This mixture was pressed into pellets with a diameter of 8 mm using 5 wt% PVA (Poly Vinyl Alcohol) as a binder, and heated at 500 ℃ for 5 h to volatilize the PVA.
The pellets were sintered at 1450 ℃ for 4 h in air.

reference_steps: All raw materials were dried in oven at approximately 120°C for 5 hours.
Weighed raw materials were mixed by ball milling for 12 hours with ethanol as medium.
Raw materials slurry was dried in oven.
Dried raw materials were calcined at 850°C for 2 hours to obtain object composition.
Calcined powder was secondly ball milled for another 12 hours to reduce particle size.
Calcined powder was dried in oven and granulated by passing through 80 mesh sieve.
5 wt% PVA aqueous solution was added as binder (approximately 10 wt% of powder mass).
Disk shape green bodies were pressed under uniaxial pressing.
Green bodies were heated to 800°C for 2 hours to remove binder.
Green bodies were sintered at 1140-1180°C for 2 hours.
As-sintered ceramic disks were polished and heated to 1100°C for 1 hour then removed directly from furnace for rapid cooling.
Silver electrodes were prepared on both surfaces of disks.
Ceramic samples were poled under electrical field of 4-7 MV/m for 5 minutes at room temperature.
test_steps: All raw materials were dried in an oven at approximately 120°C for 5 hours.
The weighed raw materials were mixed by ball milling for 12 hours with ethanol as a medium.
The dried raw materials were calcined at 850°C for 2 hours to obtain the object composition of NBBT100x ceramics.
The calcined powder was secondly ball milled for another 12 hours to reduce the particle size.
The calcined powder was dried in an oven and granulated by passing through 80 mesh sieve.
Polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) aqueous solution (5 wt. %) was added as a binder, and the amount is approximately 10 wt.% of the powder mass.
The green bodies were heated to 800°C for 2 hours to remove the binder.
NBBT100x green bodies were sintered at 1140°C-1180°C for 2 hours.
The polished ceramic disks were heated to 1100°C for 1 hour and then removed directly from the furnace to air for a rapid cooling.

family.reference: Aurivillius-type ceramics or BLSF or CaBi2Nb2O9 or CBNO

reference_steps: Raw materials were precisely weighed according to stoichiometric ratios.
Materials were ball milled for 8 hours using ethanol as dispersion medium.
Mixed raw materials were dried and calcined at 850°C for 4 hours.
Calcined powder was ground again under same condition.
Obtained powder was dried, ground, and compressed into disk with diameter of 8 mm under pressure of 250 MPa.
Ceramics were sintered at 1100°C for 4 hours.
For electrical property testing, both sides were polished and coated with silver or platinum electrodes.
Samples were immersed in silicone oil at 180°C and electric field of 150-200 kV/cm was applied for 30 minutes for polarization.
test_steps: The raw materials were precisely weighed according to the stoichiometric ratios of CLCBN-100xWM.
Ethanol was utilized as the dispersion medium for ball milling for 8 h.
The mixed raw materials were subsequently dried and calcined at 850 °C for 4 h.
The obtained powder was then dried, ground, and compressed into a disk with a diameter of 8 mm under a pressure of 250 MPa.
Finally, the disks were sintered at a temperature of 1100 °C for 4 h.

reference_steps: KICET-PZT8 piezoelectric powder, paraffin wax, ethylene-vinyl-acetate, and polystyrene were uniformly mixed using heated double planetary mixer.
Mixture was heated and extruded using twin-screw extruder to prepare piezoelectric feedstock.
Preform of 1-3 type composite was fabricated using ceramic injection molding machine with prepared feedstock.
PZT composite preform was sintered at 1250°C for 2 hours.
Polymer (EPOTEK 301) was poured into sintered preform.
Polymer-poured specimens were cured at 80°C for 12 hours.
Final cured specimens were machined into shapes optimized by simulation.
Room-temperature-curing silver electrodes were applied to machined specimens.
Polarization was performed by applying electric field of 2.5 kV/mm for 20 minutes in silicone oil bath at 120°C.
test_steps: The piezoelectric feedstock was prepared using a binder system consisting of KICET-PZT8 piezoelectric powder, paraffin wax, and ethylene-vinyl-acetate (EVA).
The preform of the 1-3 type composite was fabricated using a ceramic injection molding (CIM) machine (NEX-500, NISSEI Japan) with the prepared feedstock.
The PZT composite preform was sintered at 1250 °C for 2 h.
A polymer (301, EPOTEK) was poured into the sintered preform.
The polymer-poured specimens were cured at 80 °C for 12 h.
The final cured specimens were machined into shapes optimized by simulation.
Room-temperature-curing silver electrodes were applied to the machined specimens.
Polarization was performed by applying an electric field of 2.5 kV/mm for 20 min in a silicone oil bath at 120 °C.

reference_steps: Raw materials were weighed according to stoichiometric ratio and mixed by ball-milling with ZrO2 balls in ethanol for 12 hours.
Dried mixtures were calcined at 850°C for 2 hours.
Additional 24-hour ball-milling was performed under same conditions.
Synthesized powders were ground and granulated with PVA binder.
Powders were pressed into discs measuring 12 mm diameter and 1 mm thickness under pressure of 150 MPa.
PVA was removed by heating at 650°C.
Green samples were sintered in muffle furnace at 1150°C for 3 hours (CBN) or 1100-1140°C for 3 hours (Tm-substituted CBN).
For textured ceramics: powders were placed in graphite die and heated to 990°C for 3 minutes under 60 MPa load using SPS.
Block was deformed in larger graphite die at 1130°C for 5 minutes under 40 MPa load.
Samples were annealed in muffle furnace at 1000°C for 4 hours in air.
Test surfaces were plated with heat-resistant electrodes and sintered at 570°C for 30 minutes (silver) or 950°C for 30 minutes (platinum).
Samples were poled under DC electric field of 12-15 kV/mm at 180°C for 15 minutes.
test_steps: The raw materials were weighed according to the stoichiometric ratio of the general formula and mixed by ball-milling with ZrO2 balls in ethanol for 12 hours.
The dried mixtures were then calcined at 850 °C for 2 hours.
The mixtures were subjected to an additional 24-hour ball-milling under the same conditions.

The synthesized CBN-100xTm powders were ground and granulated with a polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binder, then pressed into discs measuring 12 mm in diameter and 1 mm in thickness under a pressure of 150 MPa.
The PVA was removed by heating at 650 °C.

The green samples were sintered in a muffle furnace. For CaBi2Nb2O9 ceramics, the sintering was done at 1150 °C for 3 hours, while thulium-substituted CBN ceramics were sintered at temperatures ranging from 1100 to 1140 °C for 3 hours.

Textured ceramics were prepared using a two-step sintering method with a spark plasma sintering (SPS) system. Initially, the CBN-100xTm powders were placed into a graphite die with an inner diameter of 10 mm and heated to 990 °C for 3 minutes at a heating rate of 100 °C/min under a constant load of 60 MPa, forming a fully densified block.

This block was then deformed in another graphite die with a larger inner diameter of 20 mm at 1130 °C for 5 minutes under a constant load of 40 MPa. The heating rate for this step remained 100 °C/min.
After sintering, the samples were annealed in a muffle furnace at 1000 °C for 4 hours in air to remove any infiltrated carbon.

reference_steps: For SnS2: 4 mmol thioacetamide and 2 mmol SnCl4·5H2O were dissolved in 80 mL absolute ethanol by stirring for 30 minutes.
Mixture solution was transferred to Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 160°C for 12 hours.
After naturally cooling to room temperature, SnS2 was obtained through washing, centrifugation, and drying at 60°C.
For CdS: 20 mmol Cd(NO3)2·4H2O were combined with 60 mL ethylenediamine and stirred until transparent solution formed.
60 mmol thiourea was added to solution and magnetically stirred for 30 minutes.
Mixture solution was added to Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 160°C for 12 hours.
CdS was obtained through washing, centrifugation, and drying at 60°C.
For CdS@SnS2 composites: x mmol CdS precursor was dispersed in 80 mL absolute ethanol using ultrasonic agitation for 15 minutes.
Mixture of 2 mmol SnCl4·5H2O and 4 mmol thioacetamide was added to suspension and stirred at room temperature for 30 minutes.
Mixture solution was added to Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 160°C for 12 hours.
After naturally cooling to room temperature, samples were obtained through washing, centrifugation, and drying at 60°C.
test_steps: 4 mmol of thioacetamide (TAA) and 2 mmol of SnCl4·5H2O were dissolved in 80 mL of absolute ethanol by stirring for 30 min.
The mixture solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 160 °C for 12 h.
After naturally cooling to room temperature, the SnS2 can be obtained through washing, centrifugation, and drying at 60 °C.
20 mmol of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O were combined with 60 mL of ethylenediamine and stirred until a transparent solution formed.
60 mmol of thiourea was added to the solution and magnetically stirred for 30 min.
The mixture solution was added to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 160 °C for 12 h.
After naturally cooling to room temperature, the CdS can be obtained through washing, centrifugation, and drying at 60 °C.
x mmol (x = 2, 4, 6, and 8) of the previously synthesized CdS precursor sample were dispersed in 80 mL of absolute ethanol using ultrasonic agitation for 15 min.
A mixture consisting of 2 mmol of SnCl4·5H2O and 4 mmol of TAA was added to the suspension and stirred at room temperature for 30 min.
The mixture solution was added to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 160 °C for 12 h.
After naturally cooling to room temperature, the as-prepared samples can be obtained through washing, centrifugation, and drying at 60 °C.

test: Transducer characterization system (Model TraCSS®, Dhvani make, India)

high_similarity_matches.test: Transducer characterization system (Model TraCSS®, Dhvani make, India)

reference_steps: PZT ceramic discs (20 mm diameter, 2 mm thickness) were coated with silver using screen printing with silver paste.
Silver-coated discs were fired at approximately 800°C in air, resulting in 25 μm silver coating thickness.
Nickel wear plates (2 mm thick) were ground to achieve planarity of approximately 10 μm and roughness of about 1 μm.
Ni wear plate was coated with silver using DC sputtering process to thickness of about 6 μm.
Coated surface was heated in flowing hydrogen gas at 700°C for 2 hours to facilitate silver diffusion into nickel.
Additional silver coating of about 3 μm thickness was applied, bringing overall Ag coating to approximately 9 μm.
For diffusion bonding: components were placed in stainless-steel vessel and evacuated to less than 10^-3 Pa.
Vessel was heated to bonding temperature (275°C or 400°C) using split furnace.
Uniaxial pressure of 20 MPa was applied for 1 hour duration.
Vessel was allowed to cool to room temperature while maintaining pressure.
For PZT discs bonded at 400°C: repoling was performed by immersing in silicone oil at 150°C and applying 15 kV DC for 15 minutes.
Bonded assemblies were subjected to thermal cycles between 250°C and room temperature for stability testing.
test_steps: Commercial PZT ceramic discs of grade SP-6 were sourced and measured 20 mm in diameter and 2 ± 0.04 mm in thickness.

Both sides of the PZT discs were coated with silver using screen printing with a proprietary silver paste, followed by firing at approximately 800°C in air to achieve a final silver coating thickness of around 25 μm.
The quality of the bond between the screen-printed silver electrodes and PZT discs was assessed using ultrasonic C-scan imaging.
Nickel wear plates, each 2 mm thick, were machined from Ni-200 rods and ground to achieve a planarity of approximately 10 μm and a roughness of about 1 μm.

The Ni wear plate was first coated with silver using a DC sputtering process to a thickness of about 6 μm, followed by heating the coated surface in flowing hydrogen gas at 700 °C for 2 h to facilitate the diffusion of silver into the nickel and establish a solid solution.
An additional silver coating of about 3 μm thickness was applied, bringing the overall thickness of Ag coating on the nickel wear plate to approximately 9 μm.
The PZT discs and nickel wear plates were placed in a vessel with a 10 mm thick plate and a special slot for positioning a sample holder, which was evacuated to a high vacuum of less than -10^-2 Pa.

The vessel was heated up to 700 °C using a split furnace, and a uniaxial press applied a predetermined pressure (up to 40 MPa) on the bonding components while maintaining the vacuum inside the vessel.
Two different bonding temperatures were used: 275 °C (below the Curie temperature, Tc, of PZT) and 400 °C (above Tc). A bonding pressure of 20 MPa was used, and the bonding duration was set to 1 h.
In cases 1 & 2, a 1 μm thick silver coating was applied over the screen-printed silver layer on the PZT disc using DC magnetron sputtering.

In cases 3 & 4, the screen-printed silver coating on the PZT disc was removed, and a ~10 μm silver was applied. After each 3 μm layer of silver was deposited, the disc was heated to 800 °C to ensure adhesion of the silver to the PZT disc.

Initially, a load of approximately 1 MPa was applied to the components, followed by evacuation of the vessel to less than -10^-2 Pa. The furnace was then put on, and once the desired temperature was reached, the final load of 20 MPa was applied.
After maintaining the components under this pressure for 1 h, the furnace was turned off, and the vessel was allowed to cool to room temperature.

The PZT discs that met the quality standards were subjected to thermal cycles between 250 °C and room temperature in air. Each cycle involved heating the PZT disc bonded to the nickel wear plate to 250 °C at a rate of 3 °C per hour, holding at that temperature for 2 h, and then furnace cooling to room temperature.
The d33 values were measured before and after the thermal cycling, and C-scan imaging of the bond was performed at the end of the first and 10th cycles.

For PZT discs bonded at 400 °C, repoling was performed using a DC poling unit. The PZT discs were immersed in dry silicone oil maintained at 150 °C, and a DC potential of 15 kV was applied across the disc for 15 min.

reference_steps: Starting materials Eu2O3, GeO2, Dy2O3, La2O3 and Ho2O3 were combined in stoichiometric ratios with each dopant at 5 mol%.
Samples were first heated at 800°C for 2 hours in pure alumina crucibles under open atmosphere.
Materials were then heated to 1150°C for 10 hours followed by slow cooling.
Resulting materials were ground into powder for further characterization.
Ceramic discs were formed from obtained powder materials with 1 mm thickness and 10 mm diameter.
Ceramic discs were compacted using uniaxial pressing under 250 MPa pressure with 2 wt% of 5 wt% PVA aqueous solution as binder.
Samples were heated at 600°C for 30 minutes to eliminate organic additives.
Sintering was conducted at 1400°C for 4 hours.
Silver paste was applied to disc surfaces and fired at 650°C for 1 hour to form surface electrodes.
Electric field of 9-18 kV/mm was applied in silicon oil bath at 120°C for 30 minutes followed by 24-hour aging.
test_steps: The starting materials were combined in stoichiometric ratios.
Simultaneous differential thermal analysis (DTA) and thermogravimetric (TG) analysis were conducted up to 1300 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min.
Based on the thermal analyses data, the samples were first heated at 800 °C for 2 h.
The samples were then heated to 1150 °C for 10 h in pure alumina crucibles under an open atmosphere, followed by slow cooling.
The ceramic discs (1 mm in thickness, 10 mm in diameter) were formed from the obtained powder materials.
The ceramic discs were compacted using uniaxial pressing under a pressure of 250 MPa and 2 wt% of a 5 wt% PVA aqueous solution as a binder.
The samples were heated at 600 °C for 30 min to eliminate the organic additives.
Sintering was conducted at 1400 °C for 4 h.
Silver paste (99.9%) was applied to the discs' surfaces, heated, and fired at 650 °C for 1 h.
The discs were polished on emery paper (1200 grit) to create smooth surfaces.
To form surface electrodes, the discs were fired at 650 °C for 1 h.

reference_steps: Raw materials BaCO3, TiO2, ZrO2, SnO2, and HfO2 were weighed according to purity and stoichiometric ratio of BaTi(1-x)(Zr1/3Sn1/3Hf1/3)xO3.
Weighed ingredients were added into alcohol and ball milled for 18 hours, then dried in oven.
Materials were calcined in muffle furnace at 1100°C for 4 hours.
Calcined materials were ball milled for 24 hours and dried again.
10 wt% polyvinyl alcohol was added to powder with uniform mixing.
Mixture was pressed into disc with diameter of 10 mm and thickness of 1 mm.
Target products were obtained by debinding process at 650°C in muffle furnace.
Final sintering process was conducted at 1350°C for 2 hours.
For piezocatalytic testing, sintered ceramics were finely ground and sieved through 100-mesh sieve.
50 mg ceramic powder was added to 50 mL dye solution and sonicated at 40 kHz, 450 W at 27-31°C for degradation testing.
test_steps: Weighed ingredients were added into alcohol and ball milled for 18 hours, then dried in an oven.
Materials were calcined in a muffle furnace at 1100°C for 4 hours, ball milled for 24 hours, and dried again.
10 wt% of polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) was added to the powder with uniform mixing and pressed into a disc with a diameter of 10 mm and a thickness of 1 mm.
Target products were obtained by a debinding process in a muffle furnace at 650°C and a sintering process at 1350°C for 2 hours.

reference_steps: Raw powders of (Bi0.5Na0.5)TiO3, BaCO3, TiO2, and MnO2 were weighed according to chemical formula for 0.85BNT-0.15BT + x wt%MnO2.
Materials were ball-milled with zirconia balls and ethanol at 250 rpm for 16 hours.
After drying at 80°C, mixture was added with 5 wt% polyvinyl butyral binder and passed through 250 µm mesh.
Mixed powder of about 0.5 g and SrTiO3 seed crystal was pressed into disc compact at 200 MPa.
SrTiO3 seed crystal was located at center of compact with size about 3 mm×3 mm×0.5 mm.
Compacts were heated at 700°C for 2 hours in air to remove binder.
Final sintering was conducted at 1200°C for 24 hours in air with heating and cooling rates of 150°C/h.
Compacts were placed on Pt sheet on alumina plate with alumina crucible lid covering during sintering.
Grown single crystals were removed from sintered compacts by cutting and polishing.
Ag paste was applied to {110}c faces and heated to 550°C to form electrodes.
test_steps: The raw powders of (Bi0.5Na0.5)TiO3, BaCO3, TiO2, and MnO2 were weighed according to the chemical formula.
The powders were ball-milled with zirconia balls with a diameter of 1 mm and ethanol at 250 rpm for 16 h.
The mixture was dried at 80 °C.
A 5 wt% polyvinyl butyral binder was added to the dried mixture and passed through a 250 µm mesh.
The mixed powder of about 0.5 g and a SrTiO3 seed crystal was pressed into a disc compact in a die with a diameter of 10 mm at 200 MPa.
The SrTiO3 seed crystal was located at the center of the compact, with its 3 mm × 3 mm faces mirror-polished and parallel to the (110) face and parallel to the faces of the compact.
Several compacts were heated at 700 °C for 2 h in the air to remove the binder.
The compacts were then heated at 1200 °C for 24 h in the air for sintering in a box-type electric furnace.
The heating and cooling rates were 150 °C/h.

reference_steps: Ta2O5, CH3COOLi·2H2O, and C4H6O6 were separately dissolved in ethanol with C4H6O6 vs. cations ratio of 2:3.
The solution was mixed with commercial LCO powders and vigorously stirred.
The mixed solution was evaporated and stirred at 80°C until a sol was formed.
The sol was aged at 120°C for 10 hours to obtain a gel.
After cooling, the gel was ground into a uniform powder.
The powder was annealed at 500°C for 12 hours and then cooled to room temperature.
For pure LTO samples, powders were compacted into disk by uniaxial pressing using polyvinyl butyral binder.
The disk was sintered in air at 500°C for 3 hours.
test_steps: A certain molar mass of Ta2O5, CH3COOLi·2H2O, and C4H6O6 (C4H6O6 vs. cations = 2:3) were separately dissolved in ethanol.
The solution was mixed with commercial LCO powders and vigorously stirred.
The mixed solution was evaporated and stirred at 80 °C until a sol was formed.
The sol was aged at 120 °C for 10 h to obtain a gel.
The powder was annealed at 500 °C for 12 h and then cooled to room temperature.
For pure LTO samples, the preparation was similar, without adding LCO during the experiment.
The LTO powders were compacted into disk by uniaxial pressing in a stainless-steel die using polyvinyl butyral binder.
The disk was sintered in air at 500 °C for 3 h.

reference_steps: Raw materials BaCO3, CaCO3, TiO2, and ZrO2 were accurately weighed according to stoichiometric ratio.
Weighed powder and moderate ethanol were mixed and ball-milled for 12 hours.
Mixture was placed into an oven and dried at 120°C.
After powder was completely dried, it was calcined at 1250°C for 5 hours.
Calcined powder was ball-milled again for 12 hours.
Ball-milled powder was pressed into desired size and shape by cold isostatic press machine at 30 MPa for 15 minutes.
Sample was sintered at 1400-1500°C for 4 hours to obtain dense ceramic plate.
For electrical property measurement, ceramic sample was sanded and polished to 0.6 mm thickness.
Ceramic plate was coated with silver paste on both sides and calcined at 600°C for 30 minutes.
Ceramic plate was polarized by DC bias of 2-3 kV/mm for 30 minutes at room temperature.
test_steps: According to the stoichiometric ratio, the raw materials were accurately weighed.
The weighed powder and moderate ethanol were mixed and ball-milled for 12 hours.
The mixture was placed into an oven and dried at 120 °C.
After the powder was completely dried, the powder was calcined at 1250 °C for 5 hours.
The calcined powder was ball-milled again for 12 hours.
The ball-milled powder was pressed into a desired size and shape by a cold isostatic press machine at 30 MPa for 15 minutes.
The sample was kept at a sintering temperature of 1400–1500 °C for 4 hours to obtain a dense ceramic plate.

reference_steps: MgO, Sc2O3 and Nb2O5 were used to synthesize precursors MgNb2O6 at 1000°C and ScNbO4 at 1150°C.
MgNb2O6, ScNbO4, TiO2 and PbO powders were weighed according to stoichiometric proportion with 2 mol% extra PbO added.
Alcohol and oxide powders were mixed in 1:1 ratio by wet-milling for 24 hours.
Combined powder was calcined at 800-850°C for 2 hours.
Calcined mixture was mixed again for 12 hours.
Powder was conglutinated with polyvinyl alcohol solution and pressed into tablets under 8 MPa.
PVA was burned off at 550°C for 2 hours.
Ceramic tablets were covered by powders with same composition and sintered at 1200-1280°C for 4 hours.
Polished samples were coated with silver electrodes on both sides.
Samples were poled at 130°C for 15 minutes under 30 kV/cm electric field.
test_steps: MgO, Sc2O3, and Nb2O5 were used to synthesize the precursors MgNb2O6 (fabricated at 1000 °C) and ScNbO4 (fabricated at 1150 °C).

MgNb2O6, ScNbO4, TiO2, and PbO powders were selected and weighed in accordance with the stoichiometric proportion and 2 mol% PbO extra was added to make up for the vaporization of PbO during sintering.
Alcohol and the above oxide powders were mixed in a 1:1 ratio by wet-milling for 24 h.
The combined powder was subjected to calcination at 800 − 850 °C for 2 h, the calcined mixture was mixed again for 12 h.
The powder was conglutinated with a solution of polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) and pressed into tablets under 8 MPa, and then the PVA was burned off at 550 °C for a duration of 2 h.
The ceramic tablets were covered by powders with the same composition to maintain a Pb-rich atmosphere and sintered at 1200 − 1280 °C for 4 h.
The polished samples (cylindrical disks with diameters of 11.40 − 11.54 mm and thickness of 0.74 − 0.90 mm) were coated with sliver electrodes on both sides in preparation for electrical tests.

family.reference: Barium Calcium Zirconate Titanate or BCZT

test_steps: The raw precursors were added to an Erlenmeyer flask, and then ethanol was added to react for 3 h to obtain polymer solutions.
The solutions were placed in the oven at 120 °C for 10 h and then calcined at 900 °C for 2 h in a muffle furnace to form precursor powders.

The powders were mixed with 2 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as an organic binder (the weight ratio of PVA and powders was 1:120) and formed into disks with a diameter of 20 mm under 20 MPa pressure with a retention time of 150 s.
The disks were embedded in alumina and sintered at 1300 °C for 4 h in air using a heating rate of 5 °C/min.
The PIMNT samples were sliced into 5×5×0.5 mm³ wafers.
Silver electrodes were painted onto sample surfaces and fired at 750 °C for 30 min to form electrodes.
The samples were then poled with an electric field of 10 kV/cm at 140 °C for 15 min in silicone oil and then slowly cooled to room temperature while the electric field was halved.
0.011 mol Bi(NO3)3 and 0.01 mol Fe(NO3)3·9H2O were weighed and dissolved into 100 mL of deionized water to obtain 0.11 M bismuth nitrate and 0.1 M iron nitrate solutions.
3 mL of 68% nitric acid was added to the bismuth nitrate solution during constant stirring until it was completely dissolved.
The two solutions were mixed and 0.02 mol of triammonium citrate was added as a complexing agent and stirred for 30 min.
The gel of the reaction intermediate was obtained by continuous stirring at 90°C until the water was completely evaporated.
The gel was calcined at 550°C for 2 h to obtain pure phase BFO powder particles.
10 mL of 0.3 M cadmium chloride solution was added to 50 mL of 0.1 M sodium citrate solution and stirred at room temperature for 20 min.
3 mL of concentrated ammonia (28%) and 10 mL of 0.6 M thiourea solution were added sequentially.
The mixed solution was reacted in a water bath at 60°C for 2.5 h.
The precipitate was collected by centrifugation, rinsed with deionized water and anhydrous ethanol, and dried in an oven at 60°C to obtain CdS nanosheets.
0.6 g of BFO was weighed into 60 mL of 0.1 M sodium citrate solution, and 1.38 mL of 0.3 M cadmium chloride solution was added according to 10 wt% of BFO, and stirred at room temperature for 3 h.
3.6 mL of concentrated ammonia (28%) and 1.38 mL of 0.9 M thiourea solution were slowly added.
The reaction was carried out at 60°C in a water bath for 2.5 h.
The precipitate was collected, rinsed with deionized water and anhydrous ethanol, and dried in an oven at 60°C to obtain 10% CdS/BiFeO3 (BC10) samples.
Cadmium chloride solution and thiourea solution could be further increased in stoichiometric ratios to obtain 20% CdS/BiFeO3 (BC20) and 30% CdS/BiFeO3 (BC30).
Prepare a 1 mg/mL solution of dipeptide in methanol.
Drop 10 μL of the dipeptide solution onto a silicon substrate.
Remove the solvent by one of the following methods: (1) spontaneous evaporation, (2) forced drying with warm air, or (3) spin-coating at 3000 rpm.
For vapor saturation, place the silicon substrate with the deposited dipeptide film in a sealed Petri dish containing an organic solvent to create saturated vapor (P/P0=1).
Keep the Petri dish at room temperature for 10 minutes to 24 hours.
After saturation, dry the film with warm air at 45°C.
Raw materials were weighed according to the nominal composition and ground in a ball mill for 12 h.
The powders were calcined at 900 °C for 2 h and then ball milled again.
After drying, the polyvinyl alcohol solution (PVA, 8 wt%) as a binder was added to the calcined powders and mixed well to form granulated powders.
The granulated powders were compressed into pellets with 10 mm in diameter and 0.85 mm in thickness.
The PVA was removed by holding the pellets at 550 °C for 4 h.
The polycrystalline ceramics were prepared by sintering at 1140 °C for 2 h.
Finally, the standard 0.6 mm thick ceramic samples were obtained by double-sided grinding.
Electrodes were made of firing gold pastes at 850 °C for 10 min.

test_steps: Each constituent was meticulously weighed according to the stoichiometric ratios.
The weighed materials were subjected to a thorough ball-milling process for a continuous period of 24 h.
The milled powders were calcined at 850 °C for 3 h.
The calcined powders were granulated and pressed into disks with 8.5 mm in diameter and 2 mm in thickness.
These green compacts were sintered within a sealed crucible at a high temperature of 1120 °C for a period of 4 h.
The formulated powders were blended in ethanol for 4 h using the planetary ball milling method.
Then calcination was implemented for 2 h at 850 °C of the dried slurries.
After secondary ball milling, the dried slurries were compressed into wafers (10 mm diameter) utilising 7 wt.% binder (polyvinyl alcohol).
Finally, the wafers were heated at 750 °C for 1 h to take out the polyvinyl alcohol and then sintering at 1100 °C for 2 h.
Deposition of a conductive buffer layer LNO on Pt/Ti/SiO2/Si substrate at 430 °C with a sputtering gas ratio of Ar:O2 (8:1), sputtering power of 90 W, and pressure of 0.5 Pa.
Growth of PMN-PZT thin films by RF magnetron sputtering from a ceramic target at 550 °C with a sputtering gas ratio of Ar:O2 (20:1), sputtering power of 150 W, and pressure of 0.5 Pa.
Adjusting the sputtering time to prepare PMN-PZT thin films of different thicknesses.
Annealing the films in a rapid thermal processing furnace with a heating rate of 30 °C/s between 600 °C and 700 °C for 20 to 40 minutes in an air atmosphere.
Deposition of Au top electrodes on the top surface of the PMN-PZT thin films using DC sputtering through a shadow mask with a radius of 0.15 mm.
Weighing precise amounts of Sc2O3, TiO2, ZnO, Bi2O3, and Pb3O4 according to the stoichiometric ratio with an excess of 1 mol% for both Bi2O3 and Pb3O4.
Subjecting the resulting powders to ball milling in alcohol for 12 h.
Drying the milled powders.
Calcining the dried powders at 750 °C for 4 h to obtain pure BZT-BS-PT ceramic powders.
Performing two rounds of milling and drying.
Carrying out a granulation process by adding 5 wt% PVA to the powder mixture.
Pressing the ceramic green body under a uniaxial pressure of 200 MPa.
Heat treating the pressed green body at 600 °C for 4 h to remove any remaining adhesive material.
Subjecting the ceramic body to a buried firing process at 1000 °C for 3 h to achieve fully densified BZT-BS-PT ceramics.

reference_steps: Raw materials were mixed with alcohol and ball milled for 24 hours.
Calcined powder was obtained by heating at 1300°C for 3 hours.
BCZT powders were produced by a second stage of ball milling for varying time periods (1-12 hours).
BCZT ceramic slurry was prepared by mixing ceramic powder with light-sensitive oligomers, diluent, photo-initiator and dispersant using vacuum mixer for 300 s at 2500 rpm.
Ceramic slurry was poured into VPP printer to produce ceramic green body with 30 μm layer thickness.
Debinding of ceramic green body was completed in tube furnace at 425°C for 4 hours with temperature ramp rates of 0.1-0.3°C/min in argon atmosphere.
Sample was kept at 550°C for 2 hours to remove residual carbon during sintering process.
BCZT ceramic scaffold was obtained by heating at 3°C/min to sintering temperature (1380-1440°C) and furnace cooling after holding for 3 hours.
Sintered BCZT ceramics were polarized at 15 kV for 1 hour using corona poling technique.
ITO film was glued to both sides of BCZT scaffold with silver glue and cured for 12 hours at room temperature.
test_steps: The raw materials were mixed with alcohol and ball milled for 24 hours.
The calcined powder was obtained by heating at 1300 °C for 3 hours.
BCZT powders for vat photopolymerization were produced by a second stage of ball milling using a range of time periods (1 h, 2 h, 4 h, 12 h).

The BCZT ceramic slurry was prepared by mixing the ceramic powder with light-sensitive oligomers, a diluent, photo-initiator, and dispersant (0.5 wt% of the ceramic powder) using a vacuum mixer for 300 s at 2500 rpm.
The ceramic slurry was poured into the VPP printer to produce the ceramic green body; the layer thickness was set to 30 μm.
Debinding of the resulting ceramic green body was completed in a tube furnace at 425 °C for 4 h, with varying temperature ramp rates of 0.1 °C min^-1, 0.2 °C min^-1, and 0.3 °C min^-1.
During the sintering process, the sample was kept at 550 °C for 2 h to remove any residual carbon.

The BCZT ceramic scaffold structure was obtained by heating at 3 °C min^-1 to the sintering temperature (1380 °C, 1400 °C, 1420 °C, 1440 °C) and furnace cooling to room temperature after holding for 3 h.
The sintered BCZT ceramics were directly polarized at 15 kV for 1 h using a corona poling technique.
A polyethylene glycol terephthalate (PET) film, covered with indium tin oxide (ITO), was glued to both sides of the BCZT scaffold with a silver glue.
The resulting piezoelectric sensor was obtained after curing for 12 h at room temperature.

reference_steps: High purity chemical powders were weighed stoichiometrically and ball milled for 24 hours at 300 rpm with alumina balls using acetone as mixing media.
Mixed powders were dried in an oven, followed by calcination at 900°C for 3 hours.
Disc-shaped pellets were prepared using ~13 mm diameter under uniaxial pressure of 200 MPa.
Sintering was carried out at 1150-1200°C for 2-4 hours.
For XRD measurements, sintered pellets were grounded and annealed at 500°C for 1 hour to remove any strain.
For electrical property measurement, samples were thinned to ~1 mm and electroded on both sides using silver paste.
Samples were annealed at 500°C for 1 hour after electrode application.
Electrical poling was done by applying DC field of 4-5 kV/mm for 15-30 min in silicone oil bath.
test_steps: High purity (>99.9 %) chemical powders of Na2CO3, Bi2O3, TiO2, BaCO3, and ZrO2 were weighted stoichiometrically.
The powders were ball milled for 24 hours at 300 rpm with alumina balls using acetone as mixing media.
The mixed powders were dried in an oven.
The dried powders were calcined at 900°C for 3 hrs.
Disc-shaped pellets were prepared using ~13 mm diameter under a uniaxial pressure of 200 MPa.
Sintering was carried out at 1150–1200°C for 2–4 hrs.
The density of the sintered pellets was measured using the Archimedes principle and found to have a relative density of ~95 % of the theoretical density.

reference_steps: Raw materials were weighed according to stoichiometric ratio of (1-x)(0.7BiFeO3-0.3BaTiO3)-x(Bi0.5Na0.5)TiO3-5 mol% Bi2O3 with x = 0.000, 0.001, 0.002, 0.003.
Materials were processed using traditional solid-state reaction method.
Ceramics were sintered to obtain final products.
Samples were poled for 24 hours at room temperature before electrical measurements.
test_steps: A series of (1-x)(0.7BiFeO3-0.3BaTiO3)- x(Bi0.5Na0.5)TiO3-5 mol% Bi2O3 (x = 0.000, 0.001, 0.002, 0.003) ceramics were prepared using the traditional solid-state reaction method.

reference_steps: LNO precursor prepared by dissolving equimolar La(NO3)3 and Ni(NO3)2 in glacial acetic acid with ethylene glycol, stirred for 1 hr.
TiO precursor prepared by dissolving Ti-n-butoxide in glacial acetic acid with ethylene glycol, stirred for 1 hr.
PZT precursor prepared by dissolving Pb(CH3COO)2 in glacial acetic acid, adding Zr(OC4H9)4 and Ti(OC4H9)4 stoichiometrically with distilled water and ethylene glycol.
10 wt% polyvinyl pyrrolidone added to PZT precursor and stirred for 1 hr, then filtered.
Buffer layers deposited by spin coating at 4000 rpm for 30 s on Pt/Ti/SiO2/Si substrate.
Buffer layers annealed at 650°C for 30 mins.
PZT film deposited by spin coating at 4000 rpm for 30 s.
Two-step annealing process: 400°C for 2 mins, then 650°C for 2 mins.
Process repeated for 12 cycles to achieve ~1000 nm thickness.
Final annealing at 650°C for 30 mins in open-air atmosphere.
Pt top electrode deposited by DC sputtering for electrical measurements.
test_steps: 0.1 M concentration is prepared by dissolving Lead (II) acetate in glacial acetic acid and stoichiometric concentration of Zirconium (IV) n-butoxide and Titanium (IV) n-butoxide is separately added with the lead precursor and stirred.
The appropriate amount of distilled water and ethylene glycol are added and stirred for 30 mins.
10 wt% of polyvinyl pyrrolidone is added and stirred for another 1 hr.
The solution is filtered using Whatman filter paper prior to deposition.
The buffer layers (TiO, LNO, LNO/TiO) are prepared by spin coating at 4000 rpm for 30 s and subsequently annealed at 650 °C for 30 mins.
The PZT film is deposited by spin coating at 4000 rpm for 30 s and it undergoes two step annealing process i.e., 400 °C for 2 mins and 650 °C for 2 mins.
All the films undergo 12 cycles to achieve the desired thickness of ~1000 nm and subsequently annealed at 650 °C for 30 mins in an open-air atmosphere furnace.

reference_steps: 1.0 mol% Mn-doped 0.28Pb(In1/2Nb1/2)O3-0.42Pb(Mg1/3Nb2/3)O3-0.30PbTiO3 single crystal grown along [001] by modified Bridgman method.
Single crystal cut into 6 × 6 × 0.38 mm³ unit sheets from same horizontal cross-section.
Unit sheets annealed at 600°C for 4 hours and cleaned.
Ultrathin conductive gold layers with 100 nm thickness deposited by sputtering method.
0.5 mm wide insulating margins left on alternating surfaces during electrode plating.
Direct current polarization along [001] direction at 135°C, 1 kV/mm for 10 minutes using CS2674 AX voltage tester in thermostatic oil bath.
15 layers of unit sheets bonded using E-44(6101) epoxy in electrical parallel and mechanical series configuration.
Zirconia ceramic sheets (0.5 mm thickness) affixed to top and bottom surfaces for rigidity.
Stacked samples subjected to 5 MPa pressure longitudinally using isostatic press.
Static curing for 48 hours to obtain final PSAs with dimensions 6 × 6 × 6.7 mm³.
test_steps: The nominal composition 1.0 mol% Mn-doped 0.28Pb(In1/2Nb1/2)O3-0.42Pb(Mg1/3Nb2/3)O3-0.30PbTiO3 single crystal was grown along [001] by the modified Bridgman method.
The single crystal was cut into 6 × 6 × 0.38 mm³ unit sheets.
To ensure the uniformity of PSAs, the unit sheets were extracted from the same horizontal cross-section of the single crystal boule.
The unit sheets were annealed at 600 °C for 4 hours and cleaned.
Ultrathin conductive gold layers with a thickness of 100 nm were deposited on the surface of unit sheets by a sputtering method.
To create an electrically parallel structure, 0.5 mm wide insulating margins were left on alternating upper and lower surfaces during the electrode plating process.

The unit sheets underwent direct current polarization (DCP) along the [001] direction, with a condition of 135 °C, 1 kV/mm, and 10 minutes, using a CS2674 AX voltage tester in a thermostatic oil bath.
15 layers of unit sheets were bonded using E-44(6101) epoxy in an electrical parallel and mechanical series configuration.
Zirconia ceramic sheets with a thickness of 0.5 mm were affixed to the top and bottom surfaces to enhance rigidity.
The stacked samples were subjected to a 5 MPa pressure applied longitudinally using an isostatic press.
The samples were statically cured for 48 hours.
PSAs were finished with dimensions of 6 × 6 × 6.7 mm³.

reference_steps: K2CO3 and Na2CO3 powders dried at 150°C for 1 h before weighing.
Powders weighed according to compositions (K0.5Na0.5)xEu0.01NbO3 with x = 0.99, 1.00, and 1.01.
Weighed powders milled with zirconia balls in ethanol for 24 hours.
Powder mixture dried at 100°C and calcined at 850°C for 4 h.
Polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) added to calcined powder as binder.
Green ceramics prepared by uniaxial pressing into pellets with 1 mm thickness and 10 mm diameter.
Green ceramics covered with same powder prior to sintering to prevent K and Na volatilization.
Ceramics heated to 850°C for 1 h to burn out PVA binder.
Final sintering at 1170°C for 3 h.
Silver paste applied to polished surface (600 μm thickness) followed by baking at 350°C for 30 min for electrical measurements.
Ceramics poled using 30 kV/cm DC electric field for 30 min at room temperature.
test_steps: K2CO3 and Na2CO3 powders were dried at 150 °C for 1 h.
The powders were weighed according to the compositions ((K0.5Na0.5)x Eu0.01NbO3 x = 0.99, 1.00, and 1.01).
The weighed powders were milled with zirconia balls in ethanol for 24 hours.
The milled powders were dried at 100 °C.
The dried powders were calcined at 850 °C for 4 h.
Polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) was added to the calcined powder as a binder.
The green ceramics were prepared by uniaxial pressing into pellets with a thickness of 1 mm and a diameter of 10 mm.
The ceramics were heated to 850 °C for 1 h to burn out the PVA binder.
The ceramics were sintered at 1170 °C for 3 h.

reference_steps: Stoichiometric raw materials weighed for (0.994-x)(K0.48Na0.52)(Nb0.97Sb0.03)O3-0.006BiFeO3-xBi0.5Na0.5ZrO3 with x=0-0.12 mol%.
Raw materials ball-milled in alcohol for 24 hours to reduce particle size.
Mixed powder dried in hot air oven at 100°C for 24 h to remove residual alcohol.
Dried powder sieved to ensure uniform particle size and calcined at 900°C for 6 h.
Fine powder pressed into pellets using uniaxial pressing at 100-200 MPa pressure.
Pellets sintered at 1120-1140°C for 3 h.
Sintered pellets divided into two portions: one polished and ground into fine particles for composite film fabrication.
Other portion polished and painted with silver paste electrodes for electrical property testing.
For composite films: KNNS-BF-3BNZ ceramic powder dispersed in ethyl alcohol using sonication for 3 h.
Dispersed powder mixed with PDMS in various proportions (0-30 wt%) and combined with curing agent (10:1 ratio).
Mixture loaded into syringe and poured into prepared mold, placed at room temperature for 48 hours.
Dried KNNS-BF-3BNZ/PDMS film cut into 3×3 cm sheets with 3 mm thickness.
test_steps: The stoichiometric raw materials were weighed and then ball-milled to reduce the particle size in alcohol for 24 hours.
The mixed powder was dried to remove residual alcohol using a hot air oven at around 100°C for 24 hours.
The dried powder was sieved to ensure uniform particle size and calcined at 900°C for 6 hours.
The fine powder was pressed into pellets using a uniaxial pressing with a pressure of about 100–200 MPa to form dense pellets.
The pellets were sintered at 1120–1140°C for 3 hours.

reference_steps: Powders of PbO, ZrO2, TiO2, Sm2O3, and Ta2O5 weighed according to [Pb0.09Sm0.01][(Zr0.54Ti0.46)1-xTax]O3 stoichiometry with x = 0, 0.01, 0.02, and 0.03.
Weighed powders subjected to wet-ball milling for 8 h.

Calcined powder sintered between 1150-1200°C for 2 h.
Ceramics coated with silver electrodes.
Poling performed in silicone oil at 150°C under 3 kV/mm electric field for 0.5 h.
test_steps: The powders of PbO, ZrO2, TiO2, Sm2O3, and Ta2O5 were weighed by the required molar proportions.
The weighed powders were subjected to wet-ball milling for 8 h.
The milled powders were then calcined at a temperature of 850 °C for 2 h.
The calcined powders were sintered between 1150 and 1200 °C for 2 h.
The ceramics were coated with silver and poled in silicone oil at 150 °C under 3 kV/mm for 0.5 h.

reference_steps: High-purity MgO and Nb2O5 powders mixed and calcined at 1100°C for 5 hours to produce columbite precursor MgNb2O6.
MgNb2O6 precursor mixed with PbO, TiO2, Sm2O3, and Pr6O11 for 2.5 mol% Sm/Pr co-doped 0.72PMN-0.28PT composition.
Mixed powders calcined at 800°C for 3 hours to generate PMN-PT powder.
PMN-PT powders pressed into 13 mm-diameter cylinders by uniaxial dry pressing.
Cylinders first sintered in oxygen atmosphere at 1200-1240°C.
Second sintering performed under uniaxial pressure of 100 MPa to improve density and eliminate porosity.
For electrical measurements, samples polished to 0.6-0.7 mm thickness.
Platinum electrodes sputtered on both surfaces.
Samples poled under DC field of 10 kV/cm for 20 minutes.
test_steps: High-purity MgO and Nb2O5 powders were mixed and calcined at 1100°C for 5 hours to produce the precursor columbite.
MgNb2O6, PbO, TiO2, Sm2O3, and Pr6O11 were mixed and calcined at 800°C for 3 hours to generate PMN-PT powder.
The PMN-PT powders were pressed into 13 mm-diameter cylinders by uniaxial dry pressing.
The cylinders were first sintered into ceramics in an oxygen atmosphere at 1200–1240°C.
The ceramics were then sintered under a uniaxial pressure of 100 Mpa to further improve the densities of the ceramics and to effectively eliminate the porosity.

reference_steps: Raw powders La2O3 and Nb2O5 mixed at mass ratio 3:2 and ball-milled in ethanol for 12 hours to prepare LN additive.
LN mixture sieved to prepare the additive.
High-purity raw powders PbO, TiO2, ZrO2, Bi2O3, and La2O3 weighed based on 0.3PT-0.65PZ-0.05BLZT formula.
Mixed powders combined with ethanol and ball-milled for 16 hours.
Mixtures dried in oven at 80°C for 1-2 hours and calcined at 820°C for 2 hours.
Synthesized powders weighed based on PT-PZ-BLZT-xLN formula (x = 0, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 wt%).
Secondary ball milling, drying, and sieving processes performed.
Granulated powders pressed into 12 mm thick sheets with 5% polyvinyl alcohol binder.
Sheets sintered at 600°C for 4 hours to remove binder.
Final sintering at 1230°C for 2 hours to synthesize ceramic samples.
Ceramic surfaces polished to uniform thickness of approximately 0.3 mm.
Silver electrodes applied to ceramic sheets for electrical measurements.
test_steps: La2O3 and Nb2O5 mixed at a mass ratio of 3:2 were ball-milled in ethanol for 12 hours, then sieved to prepare the LN additive.
High-purity raw powders of PbO, TiO2, ZrO2, Bi2O3, and La2O3 were weighed based on the 0.3PT–0.65PZ–0.05BLZT formula, combined with ethanol, and ball-milled for 16 hours.
The mixtures were dried in an oven at 80 °C for 1–2 hours and calcined at 820 °C for 2 hours.
The synthesized powders were weighted based on the PT–PZ–BLZT–xLN formula and subjected to secondary ball milling, drying, and sieving processes.
The granulated powders were pressed into 12 mm thick sheets under the granulation of 5% polyvinyl alcohol.
The sheets were sintered at 600 °C for 4 hours to remove the binder, followed by sintering at 1230 °C for 2 hours to synthesize the ceramic samples.
The ceramic surfaces were polished to maintain a uniform thickness of approximately 0.3 mm.

reference_steps: Raw materials Bi2O3, Fe2O3, BaCO3, TiO2 weighed for 0.69BiFeO3-0.31BaTiO3 composition.
Separate preparation of (0.8BNT-0.2BKT) using same solid-state method.
Weighed powders ground with zirconia balls in ethanol for 24 h.
Powder mixture dried at 100°C for 12 h.
Powder calcined in air at 760°C for 6 h at heating rate of 2°C per minute.
8 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) added to powder as binder.
Powder pressed under uniaxial pressure of 10 MPa to form discs with 8 mm diameter.
Samples sintered at 600°C for 3 h to remove PVA binder.
Final sintering at 970°C for 6 h.
Silver paste applied to surfaces and fired at 450°C for 30 min.
Silver-plated ceramic samples polarized in silicone oil at 110°C for 15 min using DC field of 5 kV/cm.
test_steps: The weighed powder was ground with zirconia balls in ethanol for 24 h.
It was dried at 100 °C for 12 h.
The powder mixture was calcined in air at 760 °C for 6 h at a rate of 2 °C per minute.
8 wt% of polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) was added to the powder as a binder and pressed under uniaxial pressure of 10 MPa to form the shape of discs with a diameter of 8 mm.
They were sintered at 970 °C for 6 h.
These samples were sintered at 600 °C for 3 h to remove the PVA.
Finally, silver paste was applied to the surfaces and fired at 450 °C for 30 min.
The silver-plated ceramic samples were then polarised in silicone oil at 110 °C for 15 min using a DC field of 5 kV/cm.

reference_steps: Raw materials Bi2O3, TiO2, Fe2O3, and Yb2O3 weighed in stoichiometric ratios for Bi5-xYbxTi3FeO15 compositions with x = 0.00, 0.02, 0.04, 0.06, 0.08, 0.10, 0.15, and 0.20.
Raw materials mixed and milled with ZrO2 balls in ethanol for 12 h.
After drying, mixture calcined at 750°C for 3 h to synthesize target product.
Calcined mixture ground, milled, and dried again under same conditions.
Resulting powder granulated with polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binders.
Powder pressed into disks 12 mm in diameter and 1.0 mm in thickness.
Each disk heated at 650°C to burn off PVA binder.
Final sintering at 1050-1060°C for 3 h at heating rate of 3°C/min in aluminum oxide crucible.
For electrical measurements, silver electrodes screen-printed on both surfaces of polished samples.
Silver electrodes fired at 570°C for 20 min.
Samples poled in silicone oil under DC electric field of 60-70 kV/cm at 150°C for 20 min.
test_steps: The raw materials were mixed and milled with ZrO2 balls in ethanol for 12 h.
After drying, the mixture was calcined at 750 °C for 3 h to synthesize the target product.
The resulting powder was granulated with polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binders and pressed into disks 12 mm in diameter and 1.0 mm in thickness.

Each disk was heated at 650 °C to burn off the PVA binder and then sintered at 1050–1060 °C for 3 h at a heating rate of 3 °C/min in an aluminum oxide crucible to prepare the ytterbium-substituted BTF ceramic samples.

reference_steps: High purity ZnO and Nb2O5 used to synthesize ZnNb2O6 precursor at 1000°C.

The mixture of ZnNb2O6 with Pb3O4, HfO2, and TiO2 was ball milled.
The ball milled mixture was calcined at 850 °C for 2 h.

The pressed mixture was sintered at 1050 °C for 2 h to form the corresponding ceramics.

reference_steps: High-purity raw materials Bi2O3, WO3, Nb2O5, and TiO2 weighed for Bi3Ti(1.5-x)NbxW0.5O9 compositions with x = 0.00, 0.01, 0.02, 0.04, 0.06.
Raw materials ball milled and crushed with zirconia balls using anhydrous ethanol as medium.

Ball milling conducted for 24 h.

Powder pelletized with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binder.
Material aged for 24 hours, then subjected to pressure of 16 MPa.
Debinding process performed to remove PVA.
Final sintering conducted in muffle furnace at temperatures between 1010-1030°C.
For electrical measurements, samples coated with silver on both sides to form electrodes.
Samples placed in silicone oil at 160°C and subjected to DC field of 11-18 kV/mm for 30 min for poling.
test_steps: Ball milling and crushing with zirconia balls and anhydrous ethanol as the media, with a mass ratio of raw material:ball mill sub:anhydrous ethanol of 1:2:1.5, for 24 hours.

Subjecting the material to a pressure of 16 MPa and subsequently debonding.

reference_steps: [001]-oriented BTO template powders synthesized from Bi2O3 and TiO2 using molten salt method with equal molar ratio of NaCl and KCl in 1:1 wt ratio.
Template powder sintered at 1100°C for 1 h.
BTO matrix powders prepared by solid-state reaction with Bi2O3 and TiO2 weighed according to stoichiometric ratio.
Raw materials calcined at 700°C for 2 h.
Calcined powder ball milled for 48-72 h to achieve small particle size.
Template and matrix powders mixed by ball milling at ~60 rpm using xylene and ethanol as solvents.
5 vol% BTO template added to solution and stirred for 1 h to ensure homogenization.
Tape casting performed with blade gap of 210 μm.
After drying at room temperature for 8-10 h, tapes cut into 10 × 10 mm squares.
Squares laminated under pressure of 75 MPa for 1-3 h.
Organics burned off at 600°C for 3 h.
Green bodies heated in tube furnace from 650°C to 1000°C at rate of 10°C/min for texture evolution assessment.
Green bodies sintered in oxygen atmosphere at 950°C for 0-6 h for electrical property measurements.
test_steps: The [001]-oriented BTO template powders were synthesized from Bi2O3 and TiO2 using the molten salt method, with an equal molar ratio of NaCl and KCl in a 1:1 wt ratio.
The template powder was then sintered at 1100 °C for 1 h.
The BTO matrix powders were prepared by a solid-state reaction, with the Bi2O3 and TiO2 powders weighed according to the stoichiometric ratio.
The raw materials were then calcined at 700 °C for 2 h.
To meet the requirements of the TGG method, the calcined powder was ball milled for 48h–72h to achieve a small particle size.
The template and matrix powders were mixed by ball milling at a mixing speed of ~60 rpm, using xylene and ethanol as solvents.
To the solution, 5 vol% of BTO template was added to the solution and stirred for 1 h to ensure homogenization.
Tape casting was performed with a blade gap of 210 μm.
After drying at room temperature for 8–10h, the tapes were cut into 10 × 10 mm squares and laminated under a pressure of 75 MPa for 1–3h.
The organics were burned off at 600 °C for 3h.
To assess the texture evolution of the BTO ceramics, the green bodies were heated in a tube furnace from 650 °C to 1000 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min.
The green bodies were then sintered in an oxygen atmosphere at 950 °C for 0–6 h to measure their electrical properties.

reference_steps: Raw materials CaCO3, Na2CO3, Pr6O11, CeO2, Bi2O3, and TiO2 weighed according to stoichiometric composition for Ca1−x(Na0.5Pr0.25Ce0.25)xBi4Ti4O15 with x = 0, 0.05, 0.10, 0.15, and 0.20.
Powders ground using planetary ball mill for 12 h with anhydrous ethanol as solvent.
Ball-milling mixture dried at 70°C for 6 h.
Dried powders calcined for 4 h at 850°C.
0.2 wt% MnO2 added to calcined powders.
Calcined powders ground using planetary ball mill for 12 h and dried again.
6 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binder added to calcined powders.
Powders pressed into discs under pressure of 6-8 MPa.
Discs heated at 600°C for 2 h to remove PVA.
Pellets sintered at 950-1050°C for 2.5 h in air.
During sintering, discs covered by their powders in sealed alumina crucibles to reduce volatility of Bi and Na.
For electrical measurements, samples poled in silicone oil bath at 180°C under DC electric field of 14-16 kV/mm for 30 min.
test_steps: The powders were ground using a planetary ball mill for 12 h, and anhydrous ethanol was used as the solvent.
The ball-milling mixture was dried at 70 °C for 6 h.
The dried powders were calcined for 4 h at 850 °C.
0.2 wt% MnO2 was added to the calcined powders.
The calcined powders were ground using the planetary ball mill for 12 h and dried again.
A 6 wt% polyvinyl alcohol binder (PVA) was added to the calcined powders, and the powders were pressed into discs under a pressure of 6–8 MPa.
The discs were heated at 600 °C for 2 h to remove the PVA.
The pellets were sintered at 950 °C-1050 °C for 2.5 h in the air.

reference_steps: Raw materials Pb3O4, SrCO3, MgO, Nb2O5, TiO2, and ZrO2 mixed according to stoichiometric ratio and accurately weighed.
Materials ball milled for 18 h.
Dried powder calcined at 850°C for 3 h.
MnCO3 added to calcined powder with Mn content x ranging from 0 to 0.8 in 0.2 increments.
Ball milled for 18 h after MnCO3 addition.
Polyvinyl butyral used as binder to press dried powder into disks with 10 mm diameter.
Organics removed at 600°C for 3 h.
Green discs sintered at 1150-1250°C for 3 h.
For electrical measurements, both sides of sintered samples coated with silver electrodes and held at 550°C for 30 min.
Ceramics polarized in 150°C silicone oil with DC electric field of 3 kV/mm for 35 min.
test_steps: The raw materials were mixed according to the stoichiometric ratio and accurately weighed.
The mixture was ball milled for 18 h.
The dried powder was calcined at 850 °C for 3 h.
MnCO3 was added and the mixture was ball-milled for 18 h.
Polyvinyl butyral was used as a binder to press the dried powder into disks with a diameter of 10 mm.
The green discs were heated to remove organics at 600 °C for 3 h.
The green discs were sintered at 1150–1250 °C for 3 h.
Both sides of the sintered circular samples were coated with silver electrodes and held at 550 °C for 30 min.
The ceramics were polarized in a 150 °C silicone oil with a direct current electric field of 3 kV/mm for 35 min.

reference_steps: Precursors bismuth(III) nitrate pentahydrate, sodium acetate, potassium acetate, titanium(IV) butoxide, and manganese(II) acetate mixed in stoichiometric ratios for 3 mol% Mn-doped 0.8(Bi0.5Na0.5)TiO3–0.2(Bi0.5K0.5)TiO3.
Propan-2-ol and acetic acid used as solvents, with pentane-2,4-dione as polymerizing agent.
Mixture stirred at room temperature at 700 rpm.
Formamide added last for drying control.
Final 0.3 M solution allowed to polymerize for seven days before deposition.
6 layers of BNKT-20-3M deposited on commercial Pt/Ti/SiO2/Si substrate via spin-coating.
Each layer spin-coated at 500 rpm for 10 s, then at 4000 rpm for 30 s.
Heat treatments applied after each layer: evaporation at 200°C, pyrolysis at 500°C, and annealing at 750°C, each for 5 min.
After annealing, layer subjected to either fast quenching in liquid nitrogen (LNQ) or air-cooling (AC) to room temperature.
Process repeated 6 times to obtain thin-film sample approximately 220 nm thick.
Some samples further heat-treated in nitrogen atmosphere at 1 atm, 750°C for 30 min for defect passivation.
Circular Pt top electrodes with area of 0.283 mm² deposited by RF magnetron sputtering to create metal-insulator-metal structure.
test_steps: Mixing the precursors in their respective stoichiometric ratios in propan-2-ol and acetic acid as solvents, with pentane-2,4-dione as the polymerizing agent.
Stirring the mixture at room temperature at 700 rpm.
Allowing the final 0.3 M solution to polymerize for seven days.
Depositing each thin-film sample consisting of 6 layers of BNKT-20-3M on a commercial Pt/Ti/SiO2/Si substrate via spin-coating.
Spinning each layer at 500 rpm for 10 s and then at 4000 rpm for 30 s.
Applying a series of heat treatments including evaporation at 200 °C, pyrolysis at 500 °C, and annealing at 750 °C, each for 5 min.
Repeating the above sequence 6 times to achieve a thin-film sample approximately 220 nm thick.
For comparison, some thin-film samples were further heat-treated in a nitrogen (N2) atmosphere at 1 atm, 750 °C for 30 min after the cooling procedure for defect passivation.
Depositing circular Pt top electrodes with an area of 0.283 mm² on the thin-film sample by RF magnetron sputtering in argon plasma.
The 0.15PSN-0.57PMN-0.28PT matrix powder, averaging 300 nm in particle size, was synthesized using the traditional solid state reaction method.
Pure perovskite matrix powder was produced by sintering the mixed raw materials at 750 °C for 2 h.
The plate-like BT templates with [001] orientation were synthesized by the topochemical transformation technique.
The embryo strips were sliced, stacked, and compressed for 30 min at 70 °C with 10 MPa of pressure.
The organic matters were discharged by sintering at 550 °C for 2 h.
Samples were subjected to isostatic pressing at a pressure of 200 MPa for a duration of 1 min.
Finally, the sample underwent sintering in an air atmosphere at 1200–1270 °C for 0–11 h.
The mixture of raw materials was ball-milled using zirconia balls (Φ = 1 mm, 3 mm, 5 mm, and 10 mm) for 24 h and dried at 90°C.
The milled PNN-PZT powders were calcined at 850°C for 4 h (heating rate: 5°C/min).
0.2 wt% of Li2CO3 was added to the calcined 0.5Pb(Ni1/3Nb2/3)O3-0.16PbZrO3-0.34PbTiO3 powder as a sintering aid.
The mixture was subsequently ball-milled for 48 h with zirconia balls (Φ = 1 mm, 3 mm, 5 mm, and 10 mm) and dried at 90°C.

Ethyl alcohol, toluene, dibutyl phthalate, polyvinyl butyral, and dispersant were mixed with PNNZT powders at an optimized ratio and ball-milled for 24 h with zirconia balls (Φ = 3 mm, 5 mm, 10 mm, and 15 mm).
After ball milling, the PNNZT slurry was separated from the zirconia balls using a mesh fabric, and any remaining air bubbles were removed using a vacuum chamber for 15 min.
An aging process followed for 2 h at 15 rpm to stabilize the slurry.
BT-template-free thick sheets were prepared via tape casting at a casting speed of 1 m/min with a blade gap of 85 μm.
The resulting PNNZT sheets had a thickness of 17 μm.

Ethyl alcohol, toluene, dibutyl phthalate, polyvinyl butyral, and dispersant were mixed with PNNZT powders at an optimized ratio and ball-milled for 24 h with zirconia balls (Φ = 3 mm, 5 mm, 10 mm, and 15 mm).
After ball milling, the PNNZT slurry was separated from the zirconia balls using a mesh fabric.
BT templates were dispersed in a small amount of ethanol using a sonicator for 5 min and then added to the separated PNNZT slurry.
Any remaining air bubbles in the slurry were removed using a vacuum chamber for 15 min.
The slurry was then aged for 2 h at 15 rpm to stabilize it.
BT-included thin sheets were prepared via tape casting at a casting speed of 1 m/min with a blade gap of 8 μm.
The resulting PNNZT-BT sheets had a thickness of 5 μm.
The obtained PNNZT and PNNZT-BT sheets were alternately laminated, one by one, using a lamination machine under 10 MPa of pressure and at a temperature of 60°C.
The laminated sheets were then subjected to a warm isostatic pressing (WIP) process to achieve denser laminates, by applying 25 MPa of pressure at 65°C for 20 min.
After the WIP process, the PNNZT/PNNZT-BT laminates were cut into 10 mm × 10 mm pieces using a blade cutter.
To burn out the organic components in the PNNZT/PNNZT-BT laminates, the cut pieces were fired at 300°C and 600°C for 5 h at each temperature, with a heating rate of 1°C/min.

Thereafter, the fired PNNZT/PNNZT-BT laminates were pressed using a cold isostatic press (CIP) machine for 1 min under 200 MPa at room temperature to compensate for the volumetric loss of organic components.
The CIP-treated specimens were then sintered at various temperatures ranging from 900°C to 1025°C, in 25°C intervals, for 15 h under an O2 atmosphere.
During sintering, the flow rate and heating rate were maintained at 1 L/min and 1°C/min, respectively.
After sintering, Ag paste was applied to both sides of the sintered body and fired at 700°C for 10 min.
Finally, poling was conducted at 3.5 kV/mm for 20 min at room temperature in silicone oil.

Ultra high-purity analytical-reagents (AR) grade chemicals were mixed homogenously for 12 hours duration as per stoichiometric ratios using a planetary ball mill with zirconia jar and zirconia balls in presence of acetone as milling agents.
The homogenous mixed powder was calcined at temperature of around 900 °C for 5 hours.

The pure phase calcined powder was mixed with an organic binder made from a 3 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) solution in deionized water and pressed in the form of pellets of 12 mm and 14 mm diameter using uniaxial pressure die at 100 MPa.

These green pellets were sintered at an elevated temperature of 1190 °C for 2 hours inside a muffle furnace by sealing it inside an alumina crucible using MgO and using pre calcined as a spacer powder.
The sintered pellet was crushed and annealed at 600 °C for 4 hours to remove any effect of mechanical strains acquired during the crushing process.

test: high temperature in-situ d33 test instrument
