test_steps: Raw materials were weighed according to the stoichiometric formula.
Excess 2 mol% Bi2O3 powders were added for the compensation due to their volatile nature.
Powders were planetary milled using ethanol as a dispersant with zirconia balls for 12 h.
The mixed oxides were dried and then calcined at 800 °C for 6 h.
After calcination, the powders were re-milled with ethanol and zirconia ball for 12 h, then dried.
The powders were mixed with 7 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) and pressed into 10 mm diameter pellets.
After burning out PVA at 300 °C for 1 h, sintering was carried out at 970 °C for 3 h.
To characterize electrical properties, the 0.5 mm thick polished samples were pasted with high-temperature silver electrodes and fired at 850 °C for 30 min.
The DC poling with 4 kV/mm electric field was carried out at 80 °C in a silicone oil bath for 20 min.
All the samples have been aged for 24 h before electrical characterizations.
The raw materials were first prepared according to the calculated ratios and then put in the planetary ball mill for 4 hours.
After drying the slurry at 100 °C and calcined at 850 °C for 2 hours.
After drying the slurry using the same method, 7 wt.% of binder (polyvinyl alcohol) was added and then the powder was well grounded.
Finally, the powder was pressed into 10 mm diameter discs and calcined at 1100 °C for 2 hours.
The raw materials powders were first placed in an oven and heated to 120 °C for 6 h.
The raw materials were weighed in accordance with the nominal stoichiometric ratio and mixed into a ball-milled tank filled with anhydrous ethanol and zirconia ball medium (HDPE material).
The mixture was mixed on a horizontal rolling ball mill at a rotating speed of 410 r/min for 24 h and then dried.
The obtained mixture was sieved by a 100-mesh sifter and then calcined at 750 °C for 6 h.
The calcined powders were subjected to secondary ball milling for 24 h, and then sieved through a 150-mesh sifter after dried.
The synthesized powders were then compacted to disks of 25 mm in diameter and 2–3 mm in thickness, followed by normal sintering in air at 1108 °C for 21 h in a muffle furnace.
As the next step, the as-grown crystals were cut out from the ceramic matrix and ground into disc-like specimens with a thickness of 0.5–0.6 mm.
The sintered samples were poled under a DC field of 30 kV/cm at 100°C for 30 min in a silicone oil bath.
The precursor powders were prepared according to stoichiometric ratios and mixed in ethanol via ball milling for 15 h.
The mixture was dried and placed into a covered alumina crucible and calcined at 810 °C for 5 h to produce the precursor powders.
The mixture was heated to 1200 °C and slowly cooled to 850 °C to promote single crystal growth.
The raw materials were weighed according to stoichiometric ratios and mixed well in absolute ethyl alcohol for 24 h with ZrO2 balls.
The slurry was then dried in an oven at 95 °C.
The dried slurry was calcined at 800 °C for 4 h.
5 wt % PVA was added to the dry powder, and the mixture was pressed into wafers with 1 mm in thickness and 12 mm in diameter at 18 MPa.
The PVA was removed by heating at 600 °C for 120 min.
The samples were sintered at 990 °C–1000 °C for 3 h.
The samples were polished with 800 mesh sandpaper and then silver paste was used to prepare samples at 600 °C for 20 min.
The ceramic samples with electrodes were polarized for 30 min under a direct current electric field of 4–5 kV/mm at 85 °C.
The quenching procedure involved annealing the samples at 970 °C for 30 min and then quenching in air.
6 mmol P25, 4-x mmol Bi2O3, x mmol La2O3, NaCl and KCl reagents were mixed and ground first (NaCl: KCl: Bi4-x La x Ti3O12 = 50: 50: 1; x = 0, 0.25, 0.75, 1.0, 1.25, 1.5, 1.75)
The mixture was calcined at 800 °C for 2h in a muffle furnace
The samples collected after calcination were washed several times with deionized water and dried in air at 80 °C
High-purity (99.99 %) Bi2O3 and TiO2 oxide powders were milled using an agate mortar and pestle to prevent agglomeration and ensure homogeneity.
The powders were dried at 150 °C to remove moisture.
The milled and dried powders were used to synthesize Bi4Ti3O12 through a solid-state reaction technique.

reference_steps: Yb2O3, MgO and Nb2O5 were used to synthesize fine YbNbO4 and MgNb2O6 precursors.
Stoichiometric PbO, TiO2, MnO2, YbNbO4 and MgNb2O6 precursors were ball-milled in ethanol with ZrO2 media.
The mixture was calcined at 775°C for 2h followed by ball milling again.
BaTiO3 platelets prepared by topochemical microcrystal conversion were used as templates.
Organic binders and solvents were mixed with the fine matrix and ball-milled.
3 vol% BT templates were added into the slurry.
The slurry was di-aired and tape-casted by a doctor blade.
The dried tapes were cut, stacked and laminated into blocks.
After binders burning out, green samples were cold isostatic pressed at 200 MPa.
Textured ceramics were sintered between 1150 and 1200°C for 6h.
To avoid lead volatilization, samples were embedded in coarse matrix powders with same compositions during sintering process.
test_steps: Yb2O3, MgO and Nb2O5 were used to synthesize fine YbNbO4 and MgNb2O6 precursors.
Stoichiometric PbO, TiO2, MnO2, YbNbO4 and MgNb2O6 precursors were ball-milled in ethanol with ZrO2 media.
The mixture was calcined at 775 °C for 2h followed by ball milling again.
BaTiO3 (BT) platelets prepared by topochemical microcrystal conversion were used as templates.
3 vol% BT templates were added into the slurry.
After binders burning out, green samples were cold isostatic pressed at 200 MPa.
Textured ceramics were sintered between 1150 and 1200 °C for 6h.
For comparison, randomly oriented Mn-doped PYN-PMN-PT ceramics were synthesized by the same procedure without addition of BT templates.

reference_steps: High purity raw materials were weighed based on stoichiometric formula for BNT-6BT ceramics.
Weighed raw materials were ball-milled for 24 h in ethanol using zirconia balls with 3 mm diameter.
Dried powders were calcined at 900°C for 4 hours.
1 mol% B3+ was added to pre-synthesized undoped and 1 mol% Mn3+ doped BNT-6BT before second milling.
Screened powders (<90 μm) were mixed with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol as binder.
Mixture was uniaxially pressed at 100 MPa pressure to form disc samples with 12 mm diameter.
Pre-shaped specimens were re-pressed via cold isostatic press at 150 MPa.
PVA binder was burnt out at 600°C for 4 h with 1°C/min heating rate.
Final sintering process was performed at 1150°C for 12 h in air.
test_steps: Weighed raw materials were ball-milled for 24 h in ethanol using zirconia balls with 3 mm of diameter.
Dried and calcined powders at 900 °C for 4 h.
Before the second milling process, 1 mol% BE^{3+} was added to both pre-synthesized undoped and 1 mol% MnE^{3+} doped BNT-6BT.
Uniaxially pressed at 100 MPa pressure disc samples with a diameter of 12 mm were shaped using the screened powders (<90 μm) mixed with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as a binder.
Pre-shaped specimens were re-pressed via a cold isostatic press (CIP) at 150 MPa.
PVA binder was burnt out at 600 °C for 4 h in the furnace set to a 1 °C/min heating rate.
A sintering process at 1150 °C was performed for 12 h in air.

reference_steps: Pure Mg substrate was mechanically ground with SiC paper up to 1000 grit and ultrasonically cleaned in ethyl alcohol.
Electrolyte was prepared with 20 g/L Na2SiO3 + 4 g/L KF + 2 g/L NaOH.
BaTiO3 powder (2 g/L or 5 g/L) was added to the electrolyte.
Mg plates were used as anode and stainless steel chamber as cathode during PEO process.
Pulse reverse power provided constant current of 2 A/dm2 for 660 s under frequency of 500 Hz and duty cycle of 15%.
Solution was cooled using water-cooling system at 30 ± 5°C during coating process.
After PEO treatment samples were rinsed in distilled water and dried in warm air.
test_steps: The substrate material (pure Mg) was mechanically ground with SiC paper up to 1000 grit, ultrasonically cleaned in ethyl alcohol, and then dried in cold air.
Mg plates were used as the anode, and a stainless steel chamber was used as the cathode and reactor.
The pulse reverse power provided a constant current of 2 A/dm² for 660 s under the frequency of 500 Hz and a duty cycle of 15%.
The electrolyte was prepared based on silicate salt (20 g/L Na2SiO3 + 4 g/L KF + 2 g/L NaOH).
The BaTiO3 content in the PEO coating is controlled by the concentration of BaTiO3 powder added to the electrolyte (2 g/L for PEO-BTO2 and 5 g/L for PEO-BTO5).
The solution was cooled down using a water-cooling system at 30 ± 5 °C during the coating process.
After PEO treatment, the samples were rinsed in distilled water and dried in warm air.
The geometry structure of pristine MoS2 unit cell was relaxed to ensure the reliability of subsequent results.
A 4 × 4 MoS2 supercell was constructed to screen which site is favorable for TM (Ni, Pd, Pt, Ir) adsorption.
TMs were adsorbed on 4 × 4, 3 × 3, and 2 × 2 MoS2 supercells to consider the influence of concentration.
The adsorption energies (E_ad) were calculated to characterize the thermodynamic stability of TMs adsorbed on MoS2.
AIMD simulations were carried out to understand the stability of the composed structures at room temperature.
The band structures of TM@MoS2 were examined to verify the semiconducting property.
The piezoelectric coefficients e_ij and d_ij were calculated to evaluate the piezoelectric properties of TM@MoS2.

reference_steps: NBT-0.6CeO2 powders (0.05-0.25 vol%) were dispersed in P(VDF-TrFE) matrix using 10 wt% DEC solvent.
Thin films were fabricated by spin-coating onto glass substrates pre-coated with aluminum electrodes.
Metal-insulator-metal structure was formed by depositing additional aluminum electrodes onto spin-coated films.
Samples were annealed at 100°C to optimize crystallinity.
For piezoelectric measurements, bulk samples were prepared by solution casting method with thickness of 30 μm.
Samples underwent DC poling at 65°C under electric field of 200 MV/m for 60 min in silicone oil bath.
Samples were slowly cooled to room temperature while maintaining electric field.
test_steps: NBT-0.6CeO2 (0.05–0.25 vol%) was dispersed in a P(VDF-TrFE) matrix using 10 wt% DEC solvent to prepare the composite.
Thin films (0.8–1 µm thickness, depending on filler concentration) were fabricated by spin-coating onto glass substrates pre-coated with aluminum electrodes.
A metal-insulator-metal (MIM) structure was formed by depositing additional aluminum electrodes onto the spin-coated films.
Samples were annealed at 100°C to optimize crystallinity.
Bulk samples for piezoelectric measurements were prepared by solution casting method (thickness of 30 µm).

method.test: solvent casting followed by hot pressing

reference_steps: 1.74 g PVDF was dissolved in 20 ml N,N-dimethylformamide at 60°C.
10-50 wt.% BCT3 filler was added to solution after four hours of PVDF mixing in DMF.
Solution was stirred at 500 rpm on hot plate for additional four hours to achieve homogeneous distribution.
Solution was cast in cleaned petri dish and annealed in oven at 100°C for 5 hours.
Films were peeled off from glass petri dish and cut into square pieces.
Films were hot pressed at 100°C by applying 125 kg/cm2 pressure for two hours.
Silver electrodes were painted on both sides of films and heated on hot plate for one hour.
Films were poled by applying DC electric field of 100 kV/cm for 1 hour before PE measurements.
test_steps: Dissolve 1.74 g of PVDF in 20 ml of N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and maintain the solution temperature at 60 °C.
Add 10, 20, 30, 40, and 50 wt.% of BCT3 filler to the solution after four hours of mixing of PVDF in DMF.
Stir the solution by setting 500 rpm on the hot plate for an additional four hours.
Cast the solution in a cleaned petri dish and anneal in an oven at 100 °C for 5 h.
Peel off the obtained films from the glass petri dish, cut into square pieces, and hot press at 100 °C by applying 125 kg/cm² pressure.

reference_steps: Raw materials were weighed according to chemical formula and adequately ball-milled for 24 h.
Powder was pre-fired in muffle furnace at 780°C for 4h at heating rate of 2°C/min.
8 wt% polyvinyl alcohol was added as binder and powder was pressed into 8 mm diameter disks at uniaxial pressure of 12 MPa.
Disks were sintered at ramp rate of 2°C/min for 3 h at 600°C to remove PVA.
Final sintering was conducted at 1000°C for 6 h to obtain ceramic wafers.
Ceramic discs with double-sided silver electrodes were polarized in silicon oil at 120°C under DC field of 5 kV/cm for 20 min.
test_steps: Raw materials were weighed according to the chemical formula and ball-milled for 24 h.
The powder was pre-fired in a muffle furnace held at 780 °C for 4 h at a heating rate of 2 °C/min.
8 wt% of polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) was added as a binder, and a small amount of the powder was pressed into 8 mm diameter disks at a uniaxial pressure of 12 MPa.
These disks were sintered at a ramp rate of 2 °C/min for 3 h at 600 °C to remove the PVA and at 1000 °C for 6 h to obtain ceramic wafers.
Finally, the ceramic discs with double-sided silver electrodes were polarized by placing them in silicon oil at 120 °C and holding them at a DC field of 5 kV/cm for 20 min.

reference_steps: Raw materials were weighed according to chemical formula and mixed using conventional solid-state reaction method.
Powders were calcined at 900°C.
Materials were sintered at 1150°C to obtain ceramic samples.
Samples were prepared for electrical measurements by applying silver electrodes.
Ceramics were poled for piezoelectric measurements.
test_steps: The powders were mixed to form the desired composition.
The mixture was calcined at 900 °C.
The calcined powders were sintered at 1150 °C.

reference_steps: Raw materials were ball milled with ethyl alcohol for 12 h at 300 r/min after weighing according to stoichiometry ratio.
Powders were dried in oven and calcined at 890°C for 6 h.
Powders were ball-milled again for 12 h.
Powder mixtures were dried, sieved, and pressed into pellets with diameter of 10 mm at 200 MPa using cold isostatic press.
Pellets were sintered in ambient air using two-step sintering technology.
Temperature was raised to 1190°C with heating rate of 10°C/min, then rapidly cooled to 1090°C and dwelled for 3-15 h.
Samples were placed in sealed crucible and covered with self-sourced powders to minimize volatilization losses.
Two sides of as-sintered samples were printed with silver paste and baked at 600°C for 30 min to form electrodes.
Samples were poled at 5 kV/cm for 30 min before piezoelectric measurements.
test_steps: The precursors were ball milled with ethyl alcohol for 12 h at 300 r/min after weighting according to the stoichiometry ratio.
The powders were dried in an oven.
The powders were calcined at 890 °C for 6 h.
The powders were ball-milled again for 12 h.
The powder mixtures were dried and sieved.
The powder mixtures were pressed into pellets with a diameter of 10 mm at 200 MPa using a cold isostatic press.
The temperature was raised to 1190 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min, and then rapidly cooled down to 1090 °C and dwelled for 3–15 h before naturally cooled down.

reference_steps: Raw materials were mixed and calcined at 700-875°C for 5 h.
Calcined powders were re-milled for 24 h at 250 rpm using planetary ball mill with ethanol and yttrium stabilized zirconia balls.
Calcined powders were filled into cylindric Molybdenum die covered with graphite foil.
Water (5 wt%) was added dropwise before upper punch insertion.
Force of 45 kN (400 MPa pressure) was applied for 40 min with gradual temperature increase of 5°C/min reaching 200°C.
Thermal post-treatment at 850°C for 25 min with lower pressure of 245 MPa and heating/cooling rate of 10°C/min in vacuum.
Samples were re-oxidized for 6 h at 850°C in oxygen to equilibrate point defects.
Both sides of polished pellets were coated with platinum via sputtering for electrical measurements.
DC poling at 2.5 kV/mm for 30 min at 120°C for piezoelectric measurements.
test_steps: Powders were mixed and then calcined at temperatures ranging from 700 to 875 °C for 5 h.
Calcined powders were re-milled for 24 h at 250 rpm using a planetary ball mill with ethanol and yttrium stabilized zirconia balls.
Cold sintering-assisted (CSA) experiments were done using an SPS machine in vacuum. A force of 45 kN (400 MPa) was applied over 40 min while maintaining a temperature increase of 5 °C/min to 200 °C.
A thermal post-treatment at 850 °C for 25 min was done with a lower pressure of 245 MPa and a heating and cooling rate of 10 °C/min.
Samples were re-oxidized for 6 h at 850 °C in oxygen to equilibrate the point defects.

reference_steps: Raw powders were weighed according to proportion of corresponding components.
Weighed materials and ethanol were poured into jar and ball milled for 24 h with ZrO2 balls.
Ball-milled powders were dried and calcined at 850°C for 6 h.
Raw powders were mixed according to proportion and ball milled for 24 h with ZrO2 balls again.
Dried mixed powders were granulated into floc with 8 wt% polyvinyl alcohol as binder.
Powders were pressed into disks (1 mm thickness, 10 mm diameter) under pressure of 10 MPa.
After removing PVA, disks were buried in calcined powders and sintered at 1150°C for 3 h in air.
Heating rate was 5°C/min from RT to 1000°C, then 3°C/min beyond 1000°C.
Both sides of sintered samples were mechanically polished and brushed with silver layer.
Samples with silver electrodes were processed at 600°C for 10 min.
Poling process was carried out in silicone oil at room temperature under electric fields of 5 kV/mm for 3 min.
test_steps: Weighed materials and ethanol are poured into a jar and ball milled for 24 h with ZrO2 balls.
Dried powders are calcined at 850 °C for 6 h.
Raw powders are mixed according to the proportion of the corresponding components, and ethanol is poured into a jar and ball milled for 24 h with ZrO2 balls.
Dried mixed powders are granulated into a floc with 8 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as a binder.
Granulated powders are pressed into disks (1 mm in thickness and 10 mm in diameter) under a pressure of 10 MPa.
PVA is removed, and the disks are buried in the calcined powders and sintered at 1150 °C for 3 h in an air atmosphere.
The heating rate of the sintering process from RT (room temperature) to 1000 °C is 5 °C/min, and 3 °C/min beyond 1000 °C.
Samples with silver electrodes are processed at 600 °C for 10 min.

reference_steps: High-purity oxides were weighed according to stoichiometric ratio.
Powders were ball-milled in ethanol medium with zirconia balls for 24 h.
After drying in oven, mixture was calcined at 850°C for 3 h.
Calcined powder underwent additional 12 h ball milling process in ethanol.
Powders were dried and granulated by adding 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol.
Mixture was sieved through 80-mesh screen to obtain uniform powder particles.
Samples were crafted by uniaxially dry pressing powder mixtures with diameter of 10 mm and thickness of 1.5 mm.
Binder was removed at 550°C.
Samples underwent sintering at rate of 3°C/min, reaching temperatures between 1120-1200°C for 2 h in ambient air.
Green discs were coated with identical powder to prevent evaporation of Pb and Bi.
Ag electrodes were applied on both surfaces and fired at 600°C for 15 min.
Ceramics were poled under electric field of 4 kV/mm at 120°C for 20 min in silicon oil.
test_steps: High-purity oxides were weighed according to the stoichiometric ratio.
The powders were ball-milled in an ethanol medium with zirconia balls for 24 h.
After drying in the oven, the mixture was calcined at 850 °C for 3 h.
The calcined powder underwent an additional 12 h ball milling process in ethanol, followed by drying and granulating by adding 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol.
Upon completion of the sieving process through an 80-mesh screen, uniform powder particles were obtained.
Samples were crafted by uniaxially dry pressing powder mixtures, each with a diameter of 10 mm and a thickness of 1.5 mm.
They underwent sintering at a rate of 3 °C/min, reaching temperatures between 1120 and 1200 °C for a duration of 2 h in an ambient air atmosphere, after the removal of the binder at 550 °C.

test: Custom-made device for piezoelectric coefficient measurement

reference_steps: Water-soluble metal salts were used as starting materials for hydro-evaporation synthesis.
After evaporation at 80°C, formed precursor precipitates were additionally heated at same temperature for 30 min to dry completely.
Dry precursor precipitates were ground in agate mortar to obtain precursor powders.
Precursor powders were calcined at 650°C for 3 h in air.
Ceramic powders were pressed uniaxially at 880 MPa in 6 mm die.
Samples were sintered at various temperatures (780°C or 835°C) for 3 h in air to achieve optimal compositions and microstructures.
Ceramic samples were sliced to 200 μm thickness for electrical measurements.
Samples were electrically poled at different electric fields during 1 s soaking time at room temperature.
test_steps: Evaporation of the precursor solution at 80 °C
Heating the formed precursor precipitates at 80 °C for 30 min to dry completely
Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the precursor powders from 30 °C to 800 °C in air with a heating rate of 20 °C/min
Calcination of the precursor powders at 650 °C for 3 h in air
Uniaxial pressing of the as-obtained ceramic powders at 880 MPa in a 6 mm die
Sintering of the pressed powders at various temperatures (780 °C or 835 °C) for 3 h to achieve the ceramic samples with optimal compositions and microstructures

reference_steps: 99.9% pure chemicals were weighed and mixed in stoichiometric ratio according to formula.
Lead loss during heat treatment was balanced with 6 wt% PbO in each composition.
Sintered powder was made fine in agate mortar.
Methanol was added as dispersing agent and left for 1 h to ensure uniform mixing.
PVA (5 wt%) was added as binder with PVA-to-ceramic powder weight ratio of 1:20.
Powder was pressed into pellets using uniaxial hydraulic press at 150 MPa pressure for 3 min.
Calcination was repeated twice to achieve homogeneous and single-phase composition.
Sintering was carried out in air atmosphere at 1150°C for 4 h.
Flat surfaces of pellets were coated with gold and silver paint electrodes applied and heated at 600°C for 30 min.
Samples were poled using Belding & McLaren method by heating to 100-110°C in silicon oil and applying DC electric field of 20-30 kV/cm.
test_steps: Weigh and mix the precursors in the stoichiometric ratio according to the formula Pb1-x-3y/2Bax Rey 3+ Nb2O6 (ReE^{3+}= NdE^{3+}, x = 0.35 and y = 0.00–0.06).
Balance the lead loss during heat treatment at 1250 °C for 2 h by adding 6 wt% of PbO to each composition.
Add methanol as a dispersing agent and leave for 1 h to ensure uniform mixing of the powders.
Add PVA (5 wt%) as a binder, with a PVA-to-ceramic powder weight ratio of 1:20.
Press the powder into pellets using a uniaxial hydraulic press at a pressure of 150 MPa, with a holding time of 3 min.
Sinter the pellets in an air atmosphere at a temperature of 1150 °C for 4 h.

reference_steps: Analytical reagents were mixed in stoichiometric ratios by ball milling with alcohol as solvent for 12 h.
Prepared powders were dried and calcined at 900°C.
Calcined powders were milled and dried again.
Powders were pressed into pellets using polyvinyl alcohol as binder.
Pellets were fired at 600°C to remove binder.
Samples were subsequently sintered at 1070°C-1170°C for 6 h under ambient atmosphere.
Sintered ceramic specimens were polished and coated with silver electrodes on top and bottom surfaces.
Optimal sintered specimen with highest d33 was selected through experimental trials by adjusting sintering temperature.
Ceramic specimens were poled in silicone oil at 4 kV/mm for piezoelectric measurements.
test_steps: The materials were mixed in stoichiometric ratios by ball milling with alcohol as a solvent for 12 h.
The prepared powders were dried and calcined at 900 °C.
The pellets were fired at 600 °C to remove the binder.
The pellets were subsequently sintered at 1070°C-1170 °C for 6 h under an ambient atmosphere.
The optimal sintered specimen with the highest d 33 was taken as the final result.

method.reference: template grain growth (TGG) with solid-state reaction

reference_steps: High purity precursors were weighed according to stoichiometric ratio and mixed by ball-milling in anhydrous ethanol for 24 h.
Mixed powders were calcined at 850°C for 5 h to form main perovskite structure.
Slurry was prepared by mixing KNNS-(0.04-x)CZ-xBAZ matrix and NaNbO3 templates in ethanol/toluene co-solvent with PVB binder and MnO2 sintering aid.
Uniform slurry was tape casted to green tapes using doctor blade with thickness of 30-50 μm.
Green tapes were cut, stacked, and uniaxially pressed under 15 MPa at 70°C for 20 min.
Organic binder was removed at 600°C.
Samples were heated to 1190°C, then rapidly cooled to 1090°C and dwelled for 10 h.
Final textured ceramics were obtained after controlled cooling.
test_steps: High purity K2CO3, Na2CO3, Nb2O5, Sb2O3, CaCO3, ZrO2, Ag2O, and Bi2O3 powders were weighted according to the stoichiometric ratio and mixed by ball-milling in anhydrous ethanol for 24 h.
The mixture was calcined at 850 °C for 5 h to form the main perovskite structure.
The slurry was prepared by mixing the KNNS-(0.04-x)CZ-xBAZ matrix and NaNbO3 (NN) templates in ethanol/toluene co-solvent with polyvinyl butyral (PVB) binder and MnO2 sintering aid.
The uniform slurry was tape casted to green tapes using a doctor blade with a thickness of 30–50 μm.
After drying, the green tapes were cut, stacked, and uniaxially pressed under a pressure of 15 MPa at 70 °C for 20 min.
The organic binder was removed at 600 °C.
The samples were heated to 1190 °C, and then rapidly cooled to 1090 °C and dwelled for 10 h.

reference_steps: High-purity raw materials were weighed according to stoichiometry ratio of 0.957K0.48Na0.52Nb0.96Sb0.04O3-0.04Bi0.5Na0.5ZrO3-0.003CaZrO3.
Materials were ball milled with ethyl alcohol for 12 h at 300 rpm.
After drying, powders were divided into 4 batches and calcined at 800, 850, 900, and 950°C respectively.
Part of powders were pressed into compacts with diameter of 10 mm at 200 MPa using cold isostatic press.
Residual powders were subjected to another ball-milling for 24 h and pressed into pellets under same conditions.
All pellets were sintered using two-step sintering technique - rapidly raised to 1190°C at 10°C/min heating rate.
Temperature was rapidly cooled down to 1090°C and dwelled for 5 h before natural cooling.
For electrical measurements, samples were printed with silver paste and baked at 600°C for 30 min to form electrodes.
Samples were poled at 5 kV/cm for 30 min and aged for 20 h before testing.
test_steps: High-purity raw materials were weighed and once ball milled with ethyl alcohol for 12 h at 300 rpm according to the stoichiometry ratio.
After drying, the powders were divided into 4 batches, which were calcined at 800, 850, 900, and 950 °C, respectively.
A part of the powders was pressed into compacts with a diameter of 10 mm at 200 MPa using a cold isostatic press (designated as group A).
The residual powders were subjected to another ball-milling for 24 h (designated as group B) and pressed into pellets under the same conditions.

All pellets were sintered by a two-step sintering (TSS) technique, while the temperature was rapidly raised to 1190 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min, and then rapidly cooled down to 1090 °C and dwelled for 5 h before naturally cooled down.

reference_steps: Starting materials were mixed in stoichiometric ratios for Ba1-xSrxTi0.92Zr0.08O3 formula with x = 0, 0.04, 0.08, 0.12, 0.16, 0.2 mol.
Materials were subjected to ball milling in ethanol at 400 rpm for 12 h.
Mixture underwent drying and then fired at 1200°C for duration of 2 h.
After calcination, material was thoroughly blended with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA).
Mixture was compacted into discs measuring 15 mm across and 1 mm thickness by applying pressure of 10 MPa.
Molded ceramics were placed in muffle furnace, ramped to 650°C at rate of 5°C/min and held for 2 h to eliminate PVA.
Samples were heated to 1400°C at 5°C/min and sintered in air for 3 h.
For electrical characterization, ceramic surfaces were uniformly coated with silver paste on both sides.
Silver paste was cured by heating at 600°C for 30 min.
Ceramics were immersed in silicone oil bath at 40°C and subjected to polarization with DC field of 30 kV/cm for 20 min.
test_steps: The starting materials were mixed in stoichiometric ratios and subjected to ball milling in ethanol at 400 rpm for 12 h.
The mixture underwent drying and then fired at 1200 °C for a duration of 2 h.
After calcination, the material was thoroughly blended with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) and compacted into discs measuring 15 mm in across and 1 mm in thickness by applying a pressure of 10 MPa.
The molded ceramics were placed in a muffle furnace, ramped to 650 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min, and held for 2 h to eliminate PVA.
It was followed by heating to 1400 °C at 5 °C/min and sintering in the air for 3 h to obtain the B1-x S x TZ piezoelectric ceramics.
For electrical characterization, the ceramic surfaces were first uniformly coated with silver paste on both sides using a screen and then heated at 600 °C for half 1 h to cure the paste.
Ultimately, the ceramics were immersed in a silicone oil bath at 40 °C and subjected to polarization with a direct-current (DC) field of 30 kV/cm for 20 min.

reference_steps: Raw materials were prepared for 0.725BiFe(1-x)ScxO3-0.275BaTiO3 ceramics with x = 0, 0.0025, 0.0050, 0.0075, 0.010, 0.015, 0.02.
Carbonates were dried in oven at 120°C for more than 2 h before use.
Raw materials were mixed by ball-milling machine in ethanol.
After drying, powder mixture was calcined twice at 800°C for 2 h.
Calcined powders were milled for 12 h and then pressed into disks with 12.7 mm diameter using polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as binder.
Green compacts were first fired at 600°C to remove PVA binder.
Samples were sintered in ambient atmosphere at temperature range of 1000°C-1020°C for 2 h.
Sintered disks were subjected to mechanical polishing to obtain thickness of ~0.35 mm.
Gold electrodes were sputtered onto ceramic surfaces for electrical measurements.
Ceramics were polarized at 120°C in silicone oil bath under DC electric field ranging from 5 to 6 kV/mm for 15-20 min.
test_steps: The carbonates were dried in an oven at 120 °C for more than 2 h before use.
The raw materials were mixed by a ball-milling machine in ethanol.
After drying, the powder mixture was calcined twice at 800 °C for 2 h.
The calcined powders were milled for 12 h and then pressed into disks with 12.7 mm in diameter using polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as a binder.
The green compacts were first fired at 600 °C to remove the PVA binder.
The green compacts were then sintered in ambient atmosphere at a temperature in the range of 1000 °C–1020 °C for 2 h.
The sintered disks were subjected to mechanical polishing to obtain a thickness of ~0.35 mm.

reference_steps: 0.74 Pb(Mg1/3Nb2/3)O3-0.26PbTiO3 (PMN-0.26 PT) single crystals were grown by modified Bridgman method.
As-grown single crystals were oriented by rotating XRD method.
[001]-oriented square slices were cut with size 4 × 4 × 0.8 mm³.
Layer of Ni was covered on (001) plane crystal slices to enhance binding force between single crystal and electrode.
Au electrode was sputtered on crystal slices for poling and electrical performance measurement.
All samples were annealed at 600°C for 10 h and then air-cooled to room temperature.
Samples were placed at room temperature for 2 days to completely release internal stress.
For electrical measurements, samples were poled using direct current poling (DCP) or alternating current poling (ACP) procedures.
During poling processes, single crystals were immersed in silicon oil to avoid arcing breakdown.
Electrical performance was measured 24 h after poling considering aging effect of materials.
test_steps: The 0.74 Pb(Mg1/3Nb2/3)O3-0.26PbTiO3 (PMN-0.26 PT) single crystals were grown by a modified Bridgeman method.
The as-grown single crystals were oriented by the rotating XRD method.
The [001]-oriented square slices were cut with size 4 × 4 × 0.8 mm³.
A layer of Ni was covered on the (001) plane crystal slices to enhance the binding force between the single crystal and electrode.
The Au electrode was sputtered on the crystal slices for poling and subsequently electrical performance measurement.
All samples were annealed at 600 °C for 10 h and then air-cooled to room temperature.
The samples were placed at room temperature for 2 days to completely release the internal stress.

reference_steps: AlN thin films were deposited by DC reactive magnetron sputtering from 100 × 300 mm² Al target (99.99% purity) using N2 and Ar as process gases.
Layers were deposited on 0.80-inch single side polished (100)-oriented Si substrates.
Substrates were cleaned in ultrasonic cleaning system: 5 minutes in Decon neutracon solvent, 5 minutes in WashBryte solvent, 5 minutes in deionized water.
Substrates were dried under N2 flow and loaded into deposition system under residual pressure around 10⁻⁷ mbar.
Al target was cleaned in pure Ar (flow of 30 sccm) at 300 W for 10 min to remove oxygen contamination.
Target was conditioned for 5 min in reactive atmosphere (Ar/N2 plasma) to reach stable reactive conditions.
AlN thin films were deposited using magnetron powers of 70-400 W and Ar & N2 flows of 20-40 sccm.
All experiments were conducted at room temperature with deposition time set at two hours.
Samples were characterized for thickness, morphology, crystallinity, and piezoelectric properties after deposition.
test_steps: Substrates (0.80-inch single side polished (100)-oriented Si) were cleaned in an ultrasonic cleaning system consisting of 5 minutes in Decon neutracon solvent, 5 minutes in WashBryte solvent, and 5 minutes in deionized water.
Substrates were dried under N2 flow and loaded into the deposition system under a residual pressure around 10E^−7 mbar.
The Al target was cleaned in pure Ar (flow of 30 sccm) at 300 W for 10 minutes to remove potential oxygen contamination from the surface.
The Al target was then cleaned in a reactive atmosphere (Ar/N2 plasma) for 5 minutes to reach stable reactive conditions of the plasma.
AlN thin films were deposited using magnetron powers of 70 and 400 W, and Ar & N2 flows of 20 and 40 sccm limits.
The thicknesses of the deposited layers were obtained by profilometry.

reference_steps: Barium acetate, calcium acetate and tin acetate were added in 2-ethylhexanoic acid in stoichiometric ratio and dissolved by heating at 80°C until clear solution was obtained.
Desired stoichiometric quantity of C16H36O4Ti was mixed in the same solvent in separate beaker and then added to the previous solution.
Final solution was stirred and mixed for 1 h under continuous heating at 80°C.
Solution was dried to obtain BCST powder.
BCST powder was calcined at 1000°C for 4 h in muffle furnace.
Calcined powder was grinded in mortar pestle with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol solution until fine powder was obtained.
Pellets were prepared by compressing under 5 ton pressure.
Pellets were sintered at 1100°C and 1200°C for 5 h to get densified BCST ceramics samples.
test_steps: Barium acetate, calcium acetate, and tin acetate were added in 2-ethylhexanoic acid in stoichiometric ratio and dissolved by heating the mixture at 80 °C until a clear solution was obtained.
The desired stoichiometric quantity of C16H36O4Ti was mixed in the same solvent in a separate beaker and then added to the previous solution.
The final solution was stirred and mixed for 1 h under continuous heating at 80 °C.
The solution was dried to obtain BCST powder.
The BCST powder was calcined at 1000 °C for 4 h in a muffle furnace.
The calcined powder was ground in a mortar pestle with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) solution until a fine powder was obtained.
Pellets of the ground powder were prepared by compressing under 5 ton pressure.
The pellets were sintered at two different temperatures, 1100 and 1200 °C, for 5 h to get densified BCST ceramic samples.
The BCST pellets were polished and coated with silver paste on both parallel faces to make electrical contact.

reference_steps: Raw materials were accurately weighed according to stoichiometric ratio and subjected to milling in alcohol with zirconia balls for 12 hours.
Materials were dried and presintered at 750°C for 2 hours.
Calcined powder underwent additional ball-milling process lasting 24 hours.
Powders were mixed with 7 wt% polyvinyl alcohol and compressed into gray disks measuring 13 mm in diameter.
Prepared disks were sintered at temperatures ranging from 1180 to 1270°C in air for 3 hours.
Samples were polished and coated with silver as electrodes to facilitate electrical characterization.
test_steps: Raw materials were accurately weighed according to the stoichiometric ratio.
Materials were subjected to milling in alcohol with zirconia balls for 12 hours.
Dried and presintered at 750 °C for 2 hours.
Calcined powder underwent an additional ball-milling process lasting 24 hours.
Powders were mixed with 7 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) and compressed into gray disks measuring 13 mm in diameter.

reference_steps: Sodium acetate, strontium acetate, bismuth acetate, and barium acetate were weighed according to stoichiometric ratio and added to ethylene glycol methyl ether and acetic acid solvents.
12 mol% excess sodium acetate and 2 mol% excess bismuth acetate were used to compensate for possible evaporation during high-temperature annealing.
Tetrabutyl titanate mixed with acetylacetone was added to the mixture of acetate.
Precursor solution was obtained after stirring the mixture at 80°C for one hour.
Solution concentration of 0.4 mol/L was achieved by adjusting the solvent content.
Solution was deposited on pretreated Pt/TiO2/SiO2/Si substrates by spin coating at 1500 r/min for 10 s and then 3000 r/min for 40 s.
Deposited film was placed in rapid thermal treatment furnace for pyrolysis at 150°C for 3 min and then at 410°C for 10 min.
Annealing process was conducted at 725°C for 3 min for crystallization.
Deposition and heating procedures were repeated 6 times to prepare thin films with designed thickness.
Au electrodes with diameter of 0.3 mm were prepared by DC sputtering.
test_steps: Sodium acetate, strontium acetate, bismuth acetate, and barium acetate were weighed in turn according to the stoichiometric ratio by an analytical balance and added to the solvents.
12 mol% excess sodium acetate and 2 mol% excess bismuth acetate were used to compensate for the possible evaporation of sodium and bismuth during high-temperature annealing.
The precursor solution of BNT-ST-100xBT solution was obtained after stirring the mixture at 80°C for one hour.
A solution concentration of 0.4 mol/L was achieved by adjusting the solvent content.
BNT-ST-100xBT solution was deposited on pretreated Pt/TiO2/SiO2/Si substrates by a spin coating method.

The solution was dropped onto the substrate, followed by rotating the substrate at 1500 r/min for 10 s and then 3000 r/min for 40 s to make the precursor solution cover the substrate surface uniformly and completely.
The deposited film was placed in a rapid thermal treatment (RTP) furnace for heat treatment.
Two pyrolysis processes were taken out, at 150°C for 3 min to evaporate the solvent and then at 410°C for 10 min to remove organic components.
The annealing process was taken out at 725°C for 3 min for crystallization.
The deposition and heating procedures were repeated 6 times to prepare BNT-ST-100xBT thin films with the designed thickness.
Au electrodes with a diameter of 0.3 mm were prepared onto the surface of thin films by DC sputtering.

reference_steps: Raw materials were precisely weighed on the basis of stoichiometric ratio and mixed in deionized water.
Materials were grounded for 6 h by ball-milling with ratio of materials to balls to water as 1:2:1.
Powder was pressed into blocks and calcined at 850°C for 2 hours.
Calcined powder was ball-milled for 12 hours again to obtain uniform PMS-PZT powder.
Dried powder combined with PVA binder was pressed into pellets of diameter 20 mm and thickness 1.4 mm at pressure of 7 MPa.
Green bodies were heated at 550°C for 3 h to remove the PVA.
Green bodies were sintered at 1250°C for 2 h in sealed alumina crucible with same composition powder on surface to minimize PbO evaporation.
Sintered ceramics were ground into thickness of 1 mm.
Silver electrodes were fired on top and bottom surfaces at 720°C for 20 min.
Ceramics were poled in silicon oil at 130°C for 40 minutes under DC electric field of 35 kV/mm.
Polarized ceramics were aged for at least 24 hours at room temperature before testing.
test_steps: The raw materials were precisely weighed on the basis of the stoichiometric ratio.
All the materials were mixed in deionized water (H2O) and grounded for 6 h by ball-milling. The ratio of materials to balls to water is 1:2:1.
After ball milling, the powder was pressed into blocks and calcined at 850 °C for 2 hours.
The calcined powder was then ball-milled for 12 hours again to obtain uniform PMS-PZT powder.
Dried powder combined with binders PVA (polyvinyl alcohol) was pressed into pellets of a diameter of 20 mm and a thickness of 1.4 mm at a pressure of 7 MPa.
The green bodies were heated at 550 °C for 3 h to remove the PVA.
Then all the green bodies were sintered at 1250 °C for 2 h in a sealed alumina crucible with the same composition powder in the surface of the disks to minimize the evaporation of PbO.
After cooling down, the sintered ceramics were ground into a thickness of 1 mm.
Silver electrodes were fired on the top and bottom surfaces of the ceramics at 720 °C for 20 min.
Then all the ceramics were poled in silicon oil at 130 °C for 40 minutes under an DC electric field of 35 kV/mm.
The polarized ceramics were aged for at least 24 hours at room temperature before testing its piezoelectric properties.

reference_steps: Raw powders were weighed according to stoichiometric formulae and ball milled for 24 h in polypropylene containers with ethanol and ZrO2 balls using planetary milling machine.
After drying the mixture, first calcination process was carried out at 850°C for 2 h to prevent volatilization of Bi3+.
Second calcination cycle was conducted at 900°C for 4 h.
Calcined powder was re-milled for 24 h and thermally treated in additional two-stage calcination process at 950°C for 4 h, followed by calcination at 1000°C for 2 h.
Obtained powder was milled again for 4 h to homogeneously reduce particle size.
Powder was mixed with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol binder in mortar and uniaxial cold-pressed into pellets with diameter of 12 mm.
Pellets were covered with powder of same composition and sintered at 1100°C for 2 h in sealed alumina crucibles.
Calcination and sintering processes were performed at heating rate of 5°C/min.
Drying procedures were carried out at 120°C on hot plate for 12 h.
test_steps: The raw powders were weighed according to the stoichiometric formulae and then thoroughly ball milled for 24 h in polypropylene containers with ethanol and ZrO2 balls using a planetary milling machine.
The first calcination process was carried out at 850°C for 2 h to prevent the volatilization of Bi3+.
The second calcination cycle was conducted at 900°C for 4 h.
The calcined powder was then re-milled for 24 h, and thermally treated again in an additional two-stage calcination process at 950°C for 4 h, followed by calcination at 1000°C for 2 h.
The obtained powder was then milled again for 4 h to homogeneously reduce the particle size.
The powder was mixed with a binder (5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol) in a mortar and then uniaxial cold-pressed into pellets with a diameter of 12 mm.
The pellets were covered with powder of the same composition and sintered at 1100°C for 2 h in sealed alumina crucibles.
The calcination and sintering processes were performed at a heating rate of 5°C/min.
The drying procedures were carried out at 120°C on a hot plate for 12 h.

reference_steps: Weighed chemicals were wet-milled in polyethylene bottles with ZrO2 balls for 12 h in ethanol.
Materials were calcined at 750°C for 3 hours.
Calcined powders were milled, dried, ground, and granulated with polyvinyl alcohol binder.
Granulated powders were pressed into discs with diameters of 12.5 mm and thicknesses of 1.0 mm at pressure of 150 MPa.
Pellets were heated to 650°C for 60 min to burn out the binder.
Samples were sintered at 1080°C for 3 h.
Sintered samples were polished to thickness of approximately 0.5 mm.
Silver paste was screen-printed onto two parallel polished surfaces, followed by firing at 570°C for 30 min.
test_steps: The weighed chemicals were wet-milled in polyethylene bottles with ZrO2 balls for 12 h in ethanol.
The milled mixture was calcined at 750 °C for 3 hours.
The calcined powders were milled, dried, ground, and granulated with a polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binder.
The granulated powders were pressed into discs with diameters of 12.5 mm and thicknesses of 1.0 mm at a pressure of 150 MPa.
The pellets were heated to 650 °C for 60 min to burn out the binder.
The samples were sintered at 1080 °C for 3 h.
The sintered samples were polished to a thickness of approximately 0.5 mm.
Silver paste was screen-printed onto the two parallel polished surfaces, followed by firing at 570 °C for 30 min.

reference_steps: Precursors were dried for minimum of 12 hours in 120°C drying oven prior to planetary ball milling.
Ball milling was conducted in 100% ethanol with 250 mL ZrO2 milling jar and 5 mm ZrO2 media for 3 h at 125 rpm.
Resulting slurry was dried using rotary evaporator, ground with agate mortar and pestle, and sieved with 250 μm mesh stainless steel sieve.
Three individual calcination pellets with nominal weight of 3.0 g and diameter of 25 mm were uniaxially pressed under 5 MPa.
Calcination pellets were calcined in partially closed alumina crucible at 801.5°C for 4 hours with heating rate of 3°C/min and cooling rate of approximately 4°C/min.
Following calcination, pellets were milled in 100% ethanol with 250 mL ZrO2 milling jar and 5 mm ZrO2 media for 30 minutes at 125 rpm.
Resulting slurry was dried using rotary evaporator, ground with agate mortar and pestle, and sieved with 150 μm mesh stainless steel sieve.
Approximately 24 sintering pellets with nominal weight of 0.30 g and diameter of 10 mm were uniaxially pressed under 30 MPa.
Pellets were isostatically pressed under 200 MPa with dwell time of one minute.
Pellets were sintered in batches of 3 in partially closed alumina crucible at 1103.5°C for 2 hours with heating rate of 5°C/min and cooling rate of approximately 4°C/min.
test_steps: Precursors were dried for a minimum of 12 hours in a 120 °C drying oven.
Ball milling was conducted in 100 % ethanol with a 250 mL ZrO2 milling jar and 5 mm ZrO2 media for 3 h at 125 rpm.
The resulting slurry was dried using a rotary evaporator, ground with an agate mortar and pestle, and sieved with a 250 μm mesh stainless steel sieve.
Three individual calcination pellets with a nominal weight of 3.0 g and a diameter of 25 mm were uniaxially pressed under 5 MPa in a stainless-steel die.
Calcination took place in a muffle furnace at 801.5 °C for 4 hours with a heating rate of 3 °C/min and a cooling rate of approximately 4 °C/min.
Following calcination, pellets were milled in 100 % ethanol with a 250 mL ZrO2 milling jar and 5 mm ZrO2 media for 30 minutes at 125 rpm.
The resulting slurry was dried using a rotary evaporator, ground with an agate mortar and pestle, and sieved with a 150 μm mesh stainless steel sieve.
Approximately 24 sintering pellets with a nominal weight of 0.30 g and a diameter of 10 mm were uniaxially pressed under 30 MPa in a stainless-steel die.
Pellets were isostatically pressed under 200 MPa with a dwell time of one minute.
Pellets were sintered in a partially closed alumina crucible in a triangular configuration with sacrificial powder on both the bottom of the crucible and the surface of each pellet.
Sintering took place in a muffle furnace at 1103.5 °C for 2 hours with a heating rate of 5 °C/min and a cooling rate of approximately 4 °C/min.
Sintered pellets were prepared to a 1 μm surface finish (silicon carbide paper to 5 μm, polycrystalline diamond paste to 1 μm) prior to SEM/EDX analysis.
Some pellets were thermally etched (1037.5 °C for 7 minutes; heating rate 5 °C/min) to increase grain boundary contrast.
All SEM/EDX specimens were carbon coated (approximately 20 nm thickness) prior to imaging with SEM/EDX.

reference_steps: Powders were precisely weighed according to stoichiometric ratios and transferred to nylon tube for 12 h of ball milling in alcohol dispersing medium.
Mixed slurry was dried and calcined at 850°C for 4 h.
Calcined powder was subsequently milled again for 12 h.
0.3 g of ceramic powder was pressed into disc with diameter of 8 mm and thickness of 1.3 mm under pressure of 250 MPa.
Surface of green bodies was covered with ceramic powder of same composition and sintered in air at 1100°C for 4 h to obtain dense ceramic sheets.
Samples were polished to required thickness and platinum electrodes were applied and cured on both sides.
Samples were polarized in silicone oil bath at 180°C under electric field of 160-200 kV/cm for 30 min.
test_steps: The powders were precisely weighed according to the stoichiometric ratios and then transferred to a nylon tube for 12 h of ball milling in an alcohol dispersing medium.
The mixed slurry was dried, calcined (850 °C, 4 h), and subsequently milled again for 12 h.
0.3 g of ceramic powder was pressed into a disc with a diameter of 8 mm and a thickness of 1.3 mm under a pressure of 250 MPa.
The surface of these green bodies was covered with ceramic powder of the same composition and sintered in air at 1100 °C for 4 h to obtain dense ceramic sheets.

reference_steps: Nonwoven ES fiber mats of P(VDF-TrFE) 80/20 were prepared from 12 wt% methyl ether ketone solution using electrospinning equipped with grounded rolling collector.

First thermal annealing (1A) process was performed by holding ES fiber mat isothermally at 140°C for various times (10, 60, 180, 360, 720, 1440, and 2880 min) to produce ECCs via chain-sliding motions in paraelectric phase.
Second annealing (2A) was carried out for ES1A-2880 min below TC with fixed isothermal time of 1 day at temperatures of 110, 115, 125, and 130°C to further increase ferroelectric domain size.
Corona-charging was employed to achieve permanent remanent polarization for piezoelectricity.
For corona-poling in water, methanol was used to wet fiber mats first and then replaced with water.
AC corona poling at 500 kHz was performed in water to avoid formation of ionic EDLs and potential electrolytic degradation.
After corona-poling in water, samples were dried in vacuum before characterization.
test_steps: Prepare 12 wt% P(VDF-TrFE) 80/20 solution in methyl ether ketone (MEK).
Use electrospinning equipped with a grounded rolling collector to prepare nonwoven ES fiber mats of P(VDF-TrFE) 80/20.
Perform first thermal annealing (1A) by holding the ES fiber mat isothermally at 140 °C for various times (10, 60, 180, 360, 720, 1440, and 2880 min).
Perform second thermal annealing (2A) for ES1A-2880 min below Curie temperature (TC) with a fixed isothermal time of 1 day at temperatures of 110, 115, 125, and 130 °C.
Apply corona-charging to achieve permanent remanent polarization (Pr0) for piezoelectricity.
The damping back cover, piezoelectric ceramic stack, flange plate, amplifying front cover, fixture rod, and tool rod are combined into a whole with a high-strength bolt made of 45-gauge steel.
The main parameters of PZT-8 piezoelectric ceramic are measured by impedance analyzer and LCR meter.
The design geometric dimensions of the HPUT are determined based on the theoretical model.
The temperature of the thermo-mechanical coupling load is limited to 25-95°C to avoid nonlinear effects.
The force of the thermo-mechanical coupling load is limited to 0-40 N for high-frequency working state.

method.reference: mixed oxide method with composite fabrication

reference_steps: BZT powder was prepared by calcining barium carbonate, zirconium dioxide and titanium dioxide at 1200°C for 2 h using mixed oxide method.
BZT powder was pressed into disc shape of ~15 mm diameter and thickness of ~1.5 mm at applied pressure of ~85 MPa.
BZT discs were sintered at 1450°C for 2 h.
BZT discs (dimension ~12 mm and thickness ~1.5 mm) were poled using electric field of 1.5 kV/mm at 50°C for 30 min in silicone oil chamber.
Poled BZT ceramic was cut using diamond saw in parallel direction along polarization axis using cut and fill method.
Mixtures of Portland cement powder, water (w/c ratio 0.35), epoxy resin and hardener (volume ratio 7.5) were prepared as matrix phase.
Mixture was filled into cut areas of BZT ceramic to create 1-3 connectivity composites with 40, 50, and 60 vol% BZT and 0, 3, 5, and 7 vol% epoxy resin.
Samples were cured in controlled chamber at 60°C for 5 days at 98% RH.
test_steps: Calcining barium carbonate, zirconium dioxide, and titanium dioxide at 1200 °C for 2 h to form BZT powder.
Pressing BZT powder into a disc shape with a diameter of ~15 mm and a thickness of ~1.5 mm at a pressure of ~85 MPa.
Sintering BZT discs at 1450 °C for 2 h.
Poling BZT discs (dimension ~12 mm and thickness ~1.5 mm) using an electric field of 1.5 kV/mm at 50 °C for 30 min in a silicone oil chamber.
Cutting poled BZT ceramic using a diamond saw in a parallel direction along the polarization axis.
Mixing Portland cement powder, water, epoxy resin, and hardener to form the matrix phase with a water to cement ratio of 0.35 and a volume ratio of epoxy resin and hardener of 7.5.
Filling the cut areas of the BZT ceramic with the matrix mixture.
Curing the samples in a controlled chamber at 60 °C for 5 days at 98 %RH.

reference_steps: Sc2O3 and Nb2O5 powders were wet-mixed via ball milling for 12 h, followed by calcination at 1050°C for 6 h to obtain precursor ScNbO4.
Precursors were mixed with PbO, ZrO2, TiO2, MnO2, and Sb2O3 before being calcined at 850°C for 2 h to achieve desired composition of PZT-PMS-PSN.
Resultant powder was crushed for 8 h and then dried.
Fine powder was mixed with PVA binder at mass concentration of 7% and pressed to form Φ10mm pellets at pressure of 150 MPa.
After binder was cremated at 800°C for 2 h, PZT-PMS-PSN samples were sintered at 1180°C for 2 h.
Sintered pellets were polished to reach about 0.5 mm thickness.
Both sides of sample were coated with silver paste and fired at 800°C for 10 min for electrical property measurements.
Samples were polarized for 30 min at 180°C in silicone oil bath at DC field strength of 5 kV/mm for piezoelectric measurements.
test_steps: Sc2O3 and Nb2O5 powders were wet-mixed via ball milling for 12 h.
The mixture was calcined at 1050 °C for 6 h to obtain the precursor ScNbO4.
The precursors were mixed with PbO, ZrO2, TiO2, MnO2, and Sb2O3.
The mixture was calcined at 850 °C for 2 h to achieve the desired composition of PZT-PMS-PSN.
The resultant powder was crushed for 8 h and then dried.
The fine powder was mixed with the PVA binder at a mass concentration of 7 % and pressed to form Φ10mm pellets at a pressure of 150 MPa.
The binder was cremated at 800 °C for 2 h.
The PZT-PMS-PSN samples were sintered at 1180 °C for 2 h.
The sintered pellets were polished to reach about 0.5 mm.
Both sides of the sample were coated with silver paste and fired at 800 °C for 10 min.
The powder was compacted into a bulk of dimensions of 15 mm × 2 mm × 2 mm.
The specimens were poled along the thickness direction.

reference_steps: Raw ingredients were weighed according to stoichiometric ratio and wet milled for 24 hours in ethanol medium using polyethylene bottles containing yttria-stabilized zirconia balls.
Milled precursors were dried in oven at 80°C overnight.
Dried powder was calcined at 1200°C for 4 hours in zirconia crucible.
Calcined powder was thoroughly ground in agate mortar to minimize particles and preserve appropriate homogeneity.
Combined powders were pelletized into disc-shaped samples using 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol binder.
Sintering was carried out for 4 hours at 1450°C at heating rate of 2°C per minute.
Sintered pellets were polished on silicon carbide paper.
Pellets were coated with silver paint on both sides and dried for 30 minutes at 600°C to facilitate electrical measurement.
test_steps: The stoichiometric ratio was used to weigh each powder.
The mixture was wet milled for 24 hours in ethanol medium using polyethylene bottles containing zirconia balls stabilized with yttria.
The milled precursors were calcined at 1200 °C for 4 hours in a zirconia crucible after being dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight.
The combined powders were then pelletized into disc-shaped samples using a 5 wt.% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binder.
At a heating rate of 2 °C per minute, the sintering was carried out for 4 hours at 1450 °C.
After polishing the sintered pellets on silicon carbide paper, pellets were coated with silver paint on both sides and allowed to dry for 30 minutes at 600 °C to facilitate electrical measurement.

reference_steps: In2Se3@SnSe S-scheme heterojunction piezo-photocatalysts were prepared using two-step hydrothermal method.
SnSe displays typical nanoplate morphology while In2Se3 exhibits nanosheet structure.
Chemical reaction involving Se in SnSe produces In2Se3 during heterojunction formation.
All In2Se3@SnSe heterojunctions exhibit flower-like spherical structure.
Varying molar content of SnSe was used to create different compositions (In2Se3@SnSe-1, In2Se3@SnSe-2, In2Se3@SnSe-3, In2Se3@SnSe-4).
Heterojunction formation results in interfacial interaction and electron transfer from SnSe to In2Se3.
test_steps: Mixing of In2Se3 and SnSe in varying molar ratios to form In2Se3@SnSe heterojunctions.
The mixture is subjected to a solid-state reaction to form the heterojunctions.
The resulting In2Se3@SnSe heterojunctions exhibit a flower-like spherical structure.

reference_steps: Raw materials were accurately weighed according to composition (1-x)(Ba0.95Ca0.05)(Ti0.89Sn0.11)O3-xBiFeO3 and milled with ethanol for 16 h.
After drying at 100°C, powders were calcined at 1150°C for 3 h.
Calcined powders were re-milled with ethanol for 16 h.
Powders were pressed into disks of 9 mm diameter using 3% PVA solution as binder.
Green bodies were fired at 600°C for 2 h and then sintered at 1400°C for 3 h.
Sintered ceramics were polished and coated with silver paste on top and bottom surfaces.
Silver-coated ceramics were fired at 800°C for 30 min to obtain electrodes.
Coated ceramics were poled at 50 kV/cm DC field for 30 min at room temperature in silicone oil bath.
test_steps: Raw materials were accurately weighed according to a composition of (1-x) (Ba0.95Ca0.05) (Ti0.89Sn0.11)O3-xBiFeO3 (BCTSO-xBFO, x = 0, 0.1, 0.5, 0.9 mol%) and milled with ethanol for 16 h.
The powders were dried at 100 °C.
The dried powders were calcined at 1150 °C for 3 h.
The calcined powders were re-milled with ethanol for 16 h.
The re-milled powders were pressed into disks of 9 mm in diameter using 3% PVA solution as a binder.
The disks were fired at 600 °C for 2 h.
The fired disks were sintered at 1400 °C for 3 h.
The sintered ceramics were polished and coated with silver paste on the top and bottom surfaces and fired at 800 °C for 30 min to obtain an electrode.
The coated ceramics were poled at 50 kV/cm DC field for 30 min at room temperature in a silicone oil bath.

reference_steps: Li-doped BaTiO3 ceramics were synthesized with varying weight percentages of Li (0 wt%, 2 wt%, and 4 wt%) using solvothermal approach
Powders were pressed into pellets for dielectric measurements
Pellets were sintered in closed environment at 1100°C for 2 hours
Care was taken to minimize lithium loss during sintering by covering samples with crucibles
test_steps: Li-doped BaTiO3 ceramics were synthesized with varying weight percentages of Li (0 wt%, 2 wt%, and 4 wt%) using the solvothermal approach.
For dielectric measurements of the samples, the powders were pressed, and the pellets were sintered in a closed environment at 1100 °C for 2 h.

reference_steps: Stoichiometric ratios of high-purity precursors BaCO3, CaCO3, ZrO2, SnO2, and TiO2 were mixed.
Combinations were ground for 2 hours in mortar and pestle.
Materials were ball milled for 4 hours in ethanol solution with zirconia balls in low-energy ball mill.
Resulting solutions were dried and obtained lumps were pulverized.
Powders were calcined for 4 hours at 1200°C in air ambient.
Resulting granulated powders were reground.
1 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) was added as organic binder.
Materials were molded into disk-shaped pellets (1 mm thick and 10 mm diameter).
Pellets were heated for 1 hour at 650°C at rate of 1°C per minute to burn off PVA binder.
Binder-free pellets underwent sintering for 4 hours at 1400°C in air.
Sintered pellets were electroded on opposite faces with conducting silver paste for electrical measurements.
test_steps: Stoichiometric ratios of high-purity precursors were mixed.
The mixture was ground in a mortar and pestle for 2 h.
The mixture was milled for 4 h in an ethanol solution with zirconia balls in a low-energy ball mill.
The resulting solutions were dried and the obtained lumps were pulverized.
The pulverized material was calcined for 4 h at 1200 °C in air ambient.
The resulting granulated powders were reground and molded into disk-shaped pellets (1 mm thick and 10 mm in diameter) with the addition of 1 wt % polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as an organic binder.
The pellets were heated for 1 h at 650 °C at a rate of 1 °C per minute to burn off the PVA binder.
The binder-free pellets underwent simultaneous sintering for 4 h at 1400 °C in air.

reference_steps: Mixed 1 g colemanite, 80 mg Fe2O3, 500 mg BaCO3, and 500 mg TiO2.
Subjected mixture to ball milling for 15 h at rotational speed of 300 rpm.
Added 2 mL of 13.8 M ammonia solution to mixture and ball-milled for additional 3 min at same speed.
Transferred resulting mixture onto silicon carbide plate (3 cm × 2 cm).
Evaporated ammonia solution by heating plate on hot plate set to 150°C.
Placed SiC plate with residual mixture into tubular furnace.
Gradually increased furnace temperature to 1300°C and maintained for 3 h under continuous NH3 gas flow.
Stopped NH3 gas flow at 975°C upon completion of reaction.
Allowed furnace to cool to room temperature.
Carefully removed composite material from SiC plate for characterization.
test_steps: A total of 1 g colemanite, 80 mg Fe2O3, 500 mg BaCO3, and 500 mg TiO2 were mixed.
The mixture was subjected to ball milling for 15 h at a rotational speed of 300 rpm.
Following the ball-milling process, 2 mL of 13.8 M ammonia solution was added to the mixture, which was then ball-milled for an additional 3 min at the same rotational speed.
The resulting mixture was transferred onto a silicon carbide plate (3 cm × 2 cm).
The ammonia solution was evaporated by heating the plate on a hot plate set to 150 °C.
Subsequently, the SiC plate with the residual mixture was placed into a tubular furnace (Protherm, Furnaces PTF 14/50/450).
The furnace temperature was gradually increased to 1300 °C and maintained for 3 h under a continuous flow of NH3 gas.
Upon completion of the reaction, the NH3 gas flow was stopped at 975 °C, and the furnace was allowed to cool to room temperature.

reference_steps: Raw materials CeO2, Bi2O3, TiO2, and Nb2O5 were weighed according to BTN-100xCe nominal composition.
Materials were ball mixed for 24 hours with anhydrous ethanol and zirconia balls medium.
Mixed slurries were separated from balls and dried.
Dried materials were calcined at 800°C for 3 hours.
Calcined materials were ball milled for 24 hours again and dried.
Dried powders were granulated with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol solution as adhesive.
Granulated powders were pressed into green pellets of 13 mm diameter and 1.0 mm thick under 120±10 MPa pressure.
Green pellets were fired at 650°C for 3 hours to burn off PVA.
Pellets were sintered at 1065-1105°C for 3 hours in air with 5°C/min heating rate.
Sintered samples were furnace-cooled to ambient temperature.
test_steps: The raw materials were weighed according to BTN-100xCe nominal composition and then ball mixed for 24 h with anhydrous ethanol and zirconia balls medium.
After separating the balls, the mixed slurries were dried and calcined at 800 °C for 3 h.
The calcined powders were ball milled for 24 h again.
The dried powders were granulated by polyvinyl alcohol solution (PVA, 5 wt%) as adhesive and pressed into green pellets of 13 mm diameter and about 1.0 mm thick under a pressure of 120 ± 10 MPa.
The green pellets were fired at 650 °C for 3 h to burn off the PVA.
The pellets were then sintered at 1065 °C–1105 °C for 3 h in air with 5 °C/min followed by furnace-cooling to ambient temperature.

reference_steps: Raw materials Ba(CH3COO)2, Ca(NO3)2·4H2O, Zr(NO3)4·5H2O, Ti(OC4H9)4 and La(NO3)3·nH2O were added to an Erlenmeyer flask to gain a polymer solution.
Solution was placed in the oven at 120°C for 10 h to obtain gels.
Gels were calcined at 900°C for 2 h to form precursor powders.
Powders were pressed into disks with a diameter of 20 mm.
Disks were embedded in alumina.
Disks were sintered at 1300°C for 4 h in air with a heating rate of 5°C/min.
Ceramic samples were obtained.
test_steps: The solution was placed in the oven at 120 °C for 10 h to obtain gels.
The gels were calcined at 900 °C for 2 h to form precursor powders.
The powders were pressed into disks with a diameter of 20 mm and the disks were embedded in alumina.
The disks were sintered at 1300 °C for 4 h in air with a heating rate of 5 °C/min.

reference_steps: Raw materials BaCO3, CaCO3, ZrO2 and TiO2 were weighed according to the stoichiometric ratio.
Raw materials were mixed with ethanol and ball-milled for 24 h.
Ethanol-ceramic slurry was dried in an oven and ground into a powder.
Powder was calcined at 1250°C for 3 h with a heating ramping rate of 5°C/min.
Calcinated powders were ground and sieved using a mesh with a size of 63 μm.
For dense ceramics: PVA was mixed with BCZT powders as binding agent.
Mixture was uni-axially cold-compacted at a pressure of 80 MPa to form green body.
Green body was heated to 500°C for 2 h using a ramp rate of 1°C/min to burn out organic agents.
Final sintering at 1400°C for 10 h with a ramp rate of 5°C/min.
Sintered ceramics were formed into dimension with thickness of 1 mm and diameter of 10 mm.
test_steps: Barium carbonate (BaCO3), calcium carbonate (CaCO3), zirconium oxide (ZrO2), and titanium oxide (TiO2) were weighed according to the stoichiometric ratio.
The raw materials were mixed with ethanol and ball-milled for 24 h.
The ethanol-ceramic slurry was dried in an oven and ground into a powder.
The powder was calcined at 1250 °C for 3 h with a heating ramping rate of 5 °C/min.
The calcined powders were ground and sieved using a mesh with a size of 63 µm.
For dense BCZT ceramics: The BCZT powders were mixed with poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) and uni-axially cold-compacted at a pressure of 80 MPa to form the green body.
The green body was heated to 500 °C for 2 h using a ramp rate of 1 °C/min to burn out the organic agents.
The green body was then sintered at 1400 °C for 10 h with a ramp rate of 5 °C/min.
For porous BCZT ceramics: The BCZT powders were ball milled for 24 h with deionized water, PVA, and ammonium polyacrylate to form a slurry with a solid loading level of ~20 vol%.
The slurry was poured into a cylindrical mold with PDMS on the sides and high thermal conductivity metal on the bottom.
The slurry was unidirectionally frozen at -80 °C, and the ice was removed by freeze drying to form a porous BCZT green body.
The green bodies formed by freeze-casting were sintered at the same conditions as the dense BCZT.
